LeadText.textfield: At Scania, we use two systems to manage our layout and grid — the Unit and the Grid System. These two systems are the fundament to everything that we design and develop.

section.Title: Unit System
section.Text:
Our base unit is a 4-pixel square. We use multiples of the base unit to create the dimensions of our columns, components and patterns along with their margins and padding to ensure coherency and consistency. Example: 8, 16, 24, 32, 40 px etc.

We do allow the base unit to be divided in 2 when needed, for instance in our spacing scale for elements, due to the size of the elements which demands smaller values.

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text:
To make sure that we create new layouts that are consistent and balanced, we should use our Unit System when sizing content, icons, components and such. See an example of how we use multiples of our base unit when sizing. Note, we have not defined any maximum size. Also, make sure to learn about how we are using our Unit System for Spacing in our elements and layouts.
Pixel Rem
8 2
16 4
24 6
32 8
40 10
48 12
56 14
64 16
72 18
80 20

section.Title: Grid System
section.Text:
A grid system is a structure containing a series of horizontal and vertical lines, used to arrange and present content such as text, imagery and graphics in a structured and well-balanced way. It provides consistency and uniformity of our brand presence and all our page layouts. 

##### Columns
Columns are the foundation of the grid system. The content is placed inside our columns. They are usually too small to contain content by themselves, but when grouped together they create harmonized, coherent and well-crafted design layouts.
 
Our grid system consists of 12 columns.

##### Margins
Our margins on each side (left and right) of the grid system are always in a fixed size within the breakpoint. It’s either 24 or 16 px depending on the breakpoint.

##### Padding
Padding is the space inside our columns which we can use to get more space between our content and components. It is possible to select if you want to use the grid system with or without paddings. 

Our padding is a defined size of 16 or 8 px depending on breakpoint.

##### Gutters
Gutter is the gap between columns, created by horizontal padding. It aims to help separating content. Our gutter width has a fixed value of 32 px, the sum of 16 px padding-right and padding-left on each column.

Sometimes a gutterless grid could be a better option when designing for specific applications. When working with a gutterless grid, we automatically get bigger columns within our grid system.

##### Breakpoints Below you will find a defined set of breakpoints, which is available as a grid package at GitHub and templates in Figma.
Breakpoint Container (max-width) # of columns Column width (px) Column width (%) Padding Margin
≥ 608 None (auto) 12 None (auto) 8.333% 8 px 16 px
≥ 608 576 px 12 48 px 8.333% 8 px 16 px
≥ 800 768 px 12 64 px 8.333% 16 px 16 px
≥ 992 960 px 12 80 px 8.333% 16 px 16 px
≥ 1184 1152 px 12 96 px 8.333% 16 px 16 px
≥ 1376 1344 px 12 112 px 8.333% 16 px 16 px
≥ 1584 1536 px 12 128 px 8.333% 16 px 24 px

section.Title: Fluid grid
section.Text:
A fluid grid allows the page layout to be adaptive, which means that the content will scale and adapt to the breakpoint size. What’s really happening is that the column size is responsive and continuously growing along with the breakpoint width — even after reaching the max. breakpoint.
 
This approach is mainly used for dashboards or specific editorial content, where it's more important to size up the content rather than slimming the amount of information down.

It is possible to have a fluid grid, both for the default grid system, with and without gutters, and also for the grid push system, which you can find out more about in the next section.

section.Title: Patterns
section.Text:
Within a user interface there are specific sections of the layout where the user expects to find specific information or navigation patterns like a header, navigation menu or a cookie bar. This is patterns, which is a group of components, that should be consistent across devices and breakpoints. They serve a global purpose — to make it easier for users to perform common user objectives and tasks. We have gathered all our patterns here (link soon available).

Some of these patterns don’t follow the grid system. We have divided these into: floating and fixed patterns. Learn more about the different types below.

##### Floating Pattern: Header
The header is a horizontal element and behaves like a fluid element, which means it should fill the entire browser window width. It doesn’t follow the grid system’s columns and responsiveness — instead it’s placed above the grid system.

##### Fixed Pattern: Left navigation
The left navigation is a vertical element and should fill the entire browser window height. It doesn’t follow the grid systems columns and responsiveness — instead the left navigation acts like a grid push and pushes the grid system to the right and aligns to web browsers left side.

When a left navigation is used, it affects the grid system’s container size, columns, gutters and padding. The left navigation is available in two states; expanded and collapsed. 
Learn more about the left navigation pattern here (link soon available).

If you have dynamic content that will be place in the grid you can use auto columns to always take the full width up to 12 col. section.Text:
If you either want to hide or show on a certain breakpoints you can use classes like sdds-hide-xlg or sdds-show-xlg. LeadText.textfield: Welcome to SDDS, Scania Digital Design System for products and digital experiences! Go through our guide below to get started designing.

section.Title: Install
section.Text:
##### Download the Grid System
Currently the Grid System is only available in Figma. Open Figma and make sure to have the most recent version installed. Then download our Grid System below.

##### Resources
Before opening the UI Kit, make sure you have the latest version of our typeface Scania Sans installed.

##### UI Kit (soon)
During Q2 2021 we will release a UI Kit which will contain all of our components, patterns, colours and text styles gathered in one library.

section.Title: Start working
section.Text:
##### Scania Digital Design System Take the time to read and educate yourself about SDDS and its design principles. Make sure that you use our Unit System when designing on your new project. A good start is to go through the documentation to understand how we use that as a fundamental base for our designs for sizing, spacing and positioning. When this is done, you will have the correct foundation to start building new digital solutions for Scania. ##### The Grid System Within the Grid Template file, we have provided a set of breakpoints for the grid system. When starting designing a new project, make sure you copy and paste these breakpoints frames you wish to design for into your new project document. To see the Grid and Units, select your frame and go to:
Menu › View › Layout Grids You can also use the following shortcut to toggle the Grid:
Control + G (MacOs)
Control + Shift + 4 (Windows)

section.Title: Contribute
section.Text:
Scania Digital Design System is an active organism, constantly evolving and adopting to meet the demands of our users. Therefore we strongly encourage and welcome contributions from the whole organisation. Together, we can update and make SDDS a better design system.

Feel free to reach out to us if you want to request a feature or propose a new design.

linkCards.title: Contribute
linkCards.detail: Functionality is essentially what the website can do and how it works.

linkCards.title: Contribute
linkCards.detail: A new design could be a new component, icon etc or a change to an existing asset of the design system.

LeadText.textfield: The SDDS toolbox will help you create an application with Scania look and feel. Here you can find styles and web components that can be used across different frameworks.

section.Title: Scania Theme
section.Text: Scania theme is a package that contains Scania specific styling for each of those components/patterns in the SDDS toolbox. Every component has a unique styling with Scania look and feel. You can expect to use SDDS design tokens from the available CSS variables, as well as Scania fonts, logotype, wordmarks, and many more. To use Scania icons and pictograms, you need to install the package separately. See the documention in the [Pictograms page](foundations/pictograms/code).

section.Title: Components
section.Text: Header, footer or a button are all web components in our design system, the difference between them is how they are technically made. `````` is a web component, while a `````` is a regular HTML element that already exist in the HTML Standard. One easy thing to differentiate between those is by looking at the dash in the element name, for example "sdds-button", that indicates it is a webcomponent. A web component can be used in the same way as a regular element in the HTML standard. The difference is what is under the hood. You can read more about it here All web-components in Scania digital design system have namespace with ``````

section.Title: Stencil
section.Text:
To be able to create a component in SDDS, it is essential to have a basic understanding of the tool we are using to make them come to life; a web component compiler called StencilJS. This is the core for our components and how we build them. You can read more in Stencil documentation. StencilJS contains features like: - Virtual DOM - TypeScript - JSX
The following is an example component:

**Loading**
Another very important part with Stencil is how the components are loaded, Stencil is built with self-lazy loading. Only the components that are used (imported) will be loaded into the application and only take that specific space in the memory. You just have to add one import for every component, instead of importing every individual component. The package size of both Scania-theme and components is something we are always trying to improve.

section.Title: Contribute
section.Text: If you come across any problems during this installation guide or feel something needs to be more clear, please contact us ou report an issue in our github. The package size of SDDS is something we are always trying to improve.

section.Title: Browser Support
section.Text:
We support the latest major browsers in SDDS 


- Chrome
- Edge (Chromium based)
- Firefox
- Safari

LeadText.textfield: There are certain things that need to be in place before a developer can start working with SDDS. A short checklist is presented below.

section.Text: ##### Prerequisites - Node.js 8 and up (Latest stable) - Node packages manager (NPM) for packages handling - If you are behind firewall, configure proxy - Install Node, follow their [documentation](https://nodejs.org/en/download/) and same regarding [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/get-npm) and [Git](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Getting-Started-Installing-Git). If you are unfamiliar with NPM and Node, we recommend that you read more about it in their documentation. When Node.js, NPM and Git are installed, you can continue! - Commands to help you see if you have installed these tools:

section.title: Node version
section.code:
> node -v
v12.18.0

> npm -v 
6.4.1

> git --version
git version 2.17.0.windows.1

section.Title: Angular
section.Text: Install SDDS components and theme in your project, this will install the latest version that is published on npm.

section.code:
> cd <You project folder>
  > npm i @scania/components
  > npm i @scania/theme-light
  > npm i @scania/icons

section.Text:
You need to import { addTheme, defineCustomElements } from components package and { theme } from Scania-theme package after you have installed them (See section Installing npm packages).

**Prerequisites**
If you are using Angular 8+, you need to add webcomponents polyfill. Install the dependency:
```
npm i @webcomponents/webcomponentsjs --save-dev
```

Import the polyfill inside `src/polyfill.ts`
```
import '@webcomponents/webcomponentsjs/custom-elements-es5-adapter.js'
```

And then, follow the steps below:

1. In Angular, go to main-ts (or some other appropriate place), and import the packages
    ```
     import { AppModule } from './app/app.module';
     //Import components and theme
     import { defineCustomElements, addTheme } from '@scania/components';
     import { theme as scania } from '@scania/theme-light';

     // Run function to initiate component
     defineCustomElements();

     // add theme
     addTheme(scania)
     ```

2. Angular doesn't recognize what a stencil component is, so what you need to do to solve this is to add CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA inside app.module.ts
   ```
   import { NgModule, CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA} from '@angular/core';
   
    @NgModule({
    declarations: [
       AppComponent,
    ],
   imports: [
     BrowserModule
   ],
   providers: [],
   bootstrap: [AppComponent],
   schemas: [CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA] // Add the Schema
   })
   ```

**Add theme in HTML**
When the previous step is done, you can start adding theme to get the styling. Add sdds-theme component high up in the hierarchy of your application. If it works you should see fonts and so on change.

```
// In app.component.html
  <sdds-theme name="scania"></sdds-theme>
  <sdds-dropdown
    placeholder="Select option">
    <sdds-dropdown-option value="option-1">Option 1</sdds-dropdown-option>
    <sdds-dropdown-option value="option-2">Option 2</sdds-dropdown-option>
    <sdds-dropdown-option value="option-3">Option 3</sdds-dropdown-option>
 </sdds-dropdown>
```

section.Title: React
section.Text: Install SDDS components and theme in your project, this will install the latest version that is published on npm.

section.code:
> cd <You project folder>
  > npm i @scania/components
  > npm i @scania/theme-light
  > npm i @scania/theme-icons

section.Text: For react application that uses typescript, you need to enable usage custom element and declare each of the web-components that you want to use from the sdds component package.

section.title: react typescript example

section.Title: Vue
section.Text: Install SDDS components and theme in your project, this will install the latest version that is published on npm.

section.code:
> cd <You project folder>
  > npm i @scania/components
  > npm i @scania/theme-light
  > npm i @scania/theme-icons

section.Text:
You need to import { addTheme, defineCustomElements } from components package and { theme } from theme package after you have installed them (See section Installing npm packages).

1. In Vue, go to main.js and import the packages
     ```
      import Vue from 'vue'
      import App from './App.vue'
     //Import components and theme
     import { defineCustomElements, addTheme } from '@scania/components';
     import { theme as scania } from '@scania/theme-light';
     ```

2. In the main.js you also need to tell the application to ignore custom-element tags such as ```sdds-accordion``` by adding this line. Otherwise a warning will be thrown in the console.
   ```
  //Ignore all components custom-elements named sdds-*
  Vue.config.ignoredElements = [/sdds-\w*/];
   ```

3. You need to call defineCustomElements()
   ```
   defineCustomElements();
   ```

4. After that you need to call addTheme() , this function takes one parameter, which is the theme from theme-light packages that you imported in step 1.
```
addTheme(scania)
```

##### Add theming
When the previous step is done, you can start adding theme to get the styling. Try and add ```sdds-theme``` component high up in the hierarchy of your application. If it works you should see fonts and so on change.

section.title: Add sdds-theme and sdds components

section.Title: Typescript - Strict:false
section.Text: Typescript have a rule called strict in the tsconfig.json file that is set to true. When this rule is set to true, it will cause a error in the imports of theme-light and component package, at this time we an issue reported for that. A workaround right now is to set the rule strict: false instead.

section.Title: Theming
section.Text:
#### On white When using a component inside a container that is using a white background, you need to put `sdds-on-white-bg` on that specific container or on specific component. Some components have other variations to the component depending on the background color. What that class will do is change the css variables for those specific components to match more with the white background. - `
used on white
` - ` used on white` #### Dark theme Still in exploration phase

content.title: Getting Started Development Creating a component

section.Title: Prerequisites
section.Text:
Prerequisites to create a component

- Git installed
- Github account access

section.Title: Pre-work
section.Text:
##### Clone
After you have forked you can start cloning. Go to your cli enviorment and do the following:

Clone SDDS from your fork.
 
   ```bash
    > git clone https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds.git
  ```

##### Installing npm packages After the cloning is done, it is time to install all the npm packages. This packages are modules that we are using for different reasons, for example bootstrap, redux and other packages. You can find all our packages in our package.json file. To install our packages you need to be in your project folder, where your package.json file is run *npm install* or *npm i*:
##### Components: ```bash > cd sdds/components > npm install > npm start ```
##### Scania theme ```bash > cd sdds/theme/light > npm install > npm start ``` **Warnings(warn) might appear; Sometimes, it is not something that will cause problems* ##### Storybook You can see the project running on Storybook. Open a new terminal and run storybook. ``` cd components npm run sb ``` Visit http://localhost:6006/ to check the demo is running.

section.Title: General
section.Text:
<sdds-accordion>
  <sdds-accordion-item header="What is SDDS theme and components?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    SDDS is a framework, based on StencilJS, which provide a UI toolbox to use in your application. All components are web-components and follow the web-component standard in the browser.
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="What is Theming?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Theme is a package built with CSS(SASS) to style every component according to Scania identity guidelines.
  </sdds-accordion-item>

<sdds-accordion-item header="What is a web-component?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

  Web-components are a standard for creating elements that you can use in your application. One standard component that is using the same technology is the <video></video> element. If you inspect the element with “shadow-dom show” enabled in your settings, you can see it is more to the eye than just a video element. Web-components usually consists of:

   - Custom elements
   - Shadow-DOM
   - HTML templates

  You can read more about it here: [Link](https://auth0.com/blog/creating-web-components-with-stencil/)

</sdds-accordion-item>

<sdds-accordion-item header="Is there any documentation or list of components?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

You can find the documentation of the components here: [Link](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components)

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Where do I find the Experimental components and patterns?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

We are planning to add all experimental components and pattern into Scania Digital Design System site later. Right now it is not possible to see component that is under development. You can check [design system repository](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds) to see our current backlog and components that are being developed in the moment.

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="What should I do if I find a component that isn’t accessible?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

 Contact our [team](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/support/contact)

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Where can I get help implementing the components with my project?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   Read how to use our components in the [getting started section](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/development)

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Why is SDDS so big?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

A very important part with Stencil is how the components are loaded, Stencil is built with
[self-lazy loading](https://stenciljs.com/docs/distribution).

   Only the components that are used via import, will be loaded into the application and only take that specific space in the memory.

   You just have to add one import for every component, instead of importing every individual component. The package size of both theme and SDDS will be improved to have smaller size.

   One of the reasons why it is so big is partly of the icon/pictogram solultion, which is something we are working on.

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Is there Dark mode in SDDS?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   Right now, no. But this is something that is highly demanded. The reason why we haven’t added is that it needs a lot for research before something like that can be implemented.

  </sdds-accordion-item>

<sdds-accordion-item header="I need a new icon, how do I add it?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

  - First, check if icon is available [here](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/foundation/icons)
  - Icon that has been included in Scania Media Provider but not available in SDDS: Create a [feature request](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds/issues/new/choose) with detail information about the icon that you need.
  - New icon: Contact our team for more information.

</sdds-accordion-item>

 <sdds-accordion-item header="Are there .psd or .sketch files of the components?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">Yes, you can find them here: [Link](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/resources/ui-kits)
 </sdds-accordion-item>

</sdds-accordion>

section.Title: What is supported
section.Text:
<sdds-accordion>
  <sdds-accordion-item header="Who can use the components?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Developers, with somewhat understanding of front-end development for all web based application.
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Which browsers are supported?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Chrome, Safari, Firefox and Edge
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="What JavaScript frameworks are supported?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Angular, React and Vue. More might come in the future.

   [See live examples](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/resources/development)

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Can I use SDDS on third party application?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Third part application has a very limited support, due to third-party applications is usually built differently. If you know how to import libraries and so on, please try it out!
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Why did you stop supporting font-awesome pro?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    We took the decision to start creating and using our own Scania icons. You can still use font-awesome pro, but you need to buy your own licence.
  </sdds-accordion-item>
</sdds-accordion>

section.Title: Migration
section.Text:
<sdds-accordion>
  <sdds-accordion-item header="Is it possible to migrate from Corporate-ui 3 or 4 to SDDS?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   Yes, it is! It will require some work. You can read more about it in our migration guide [link](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds/blob/master/MIGRATION.md). One thing to remember is that, not everything that was in Corporate-UI 3 and 4 will be in SDDS. We have removed and/or changed some components and dependencies that we had.

   You can see the biggest changes in the [getting started](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/overview/sdds-vs-corp-ui) section.

 </sdds-accordion-item>

<sdds-accordion-item header="What are the differences between version corporate-ui 3 and SDDS?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   One of the key things that changed are:

   - Moved from polymer to stencilJS
   - How you import a component
   - Removed bootstrap
   - Theming is added for styling components
   - Removed Font-awesome Pro support

    [Read migration guideline here](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds/blob/master/MIGRATION.md)

</sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="I haven’t updated to the latest version of Corporate UI yet, and I still need the old documentation. Where can I find it?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   - [Visit documentation for Corporate UI 3](https://scania.github.io/corporate-ui-docs/)
   - [Visit documentation for Corporate UI 4](https://digitaldesign.devtest.aws.scania.com/home/)
  </sdds-accordion-item>
</sdds-accordion>

section.Title: Contribution
section.Text:
<sdds-accordion>
<sdds-accordion-item header="How do I modify a components styling, structure or functionality?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   Depending what part of the components you want to modify:

   - Styling: SDDS/components for base component and theme/"theme-name" for specific theme
   - Structure: SDDS/components
   - Functionality: SDDS/components

</sdds-accordion-item>

<sdds-accordion-item header="I need a new component, who do I talk to? " affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

SDDS is an open source and collaborative project. It means you can develop your own component and make a pull-request to add it as a part of SDDS. [See contributing guidelines here](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
If you are not able to make your own component, you can add a feature request in our Github page : [Link to Github](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds/issues/new/choose) or contact our team.

</sdds-accordion-item>

<sdds-accordion-item header="How do I make a pull request? What branch should I pull request into?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

[Go to our github at Scania digital design system](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system)
</sdds-accordion-item>
</sdds-accordion>

section.Title: Debug
section.Text:
<sdds-accordion>
<sdds-accordion-item header="How do i debug?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   - Investigate the cause of your problem from the development window. Go to the browser, and press *Ctr+Shift+I*. Check console tab, and see the error message.
   - Version: First of you need to know which version you are using, maybe the problem is solved in later versions. Look at the HTML TAG
   - Styling/CSS/SASS problem: Look if anything is overriding our/your css first, depending on your expected input.
   - Crashing: If there is any error, which files is the error refering to? Try to investigate, remove SDDS dependencies see if the error still occurs, or try to update.
   - If you still can’t find a solution to your bug, either make a report in [Github](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds/issues/new/choose) or ask in [team channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3a1257007a64d44c64954acca27a9d4b46%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=79f9bfeb-73e2-424d-9477-b236191ece5e&tenantId=3bc062e4-ac9d-4c17-b4dd-3aad637ff1ac) for support.

</sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="How do I see which version of SDDS I’m using?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    You can see what SDDS version in the HTML tag or NPM package you have installed.
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="I see a bug. How do I report it?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   You can make an issue in [Github](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds/issues/new/choose)

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="What can I expect for a response to my bug report?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   Our team will try it's best to fix the bug as soon as possible. If you know what's causing the bug, you can contribute and add the solution to SDDS by creating a pull-request. Please provide detailed information or an idea for the solution when you report an issue. By making a more detailed issue, it will naturally make the the bug to be solved faster, depending on the severity of the issue of course.  [Read contribution guideline](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)

  </sdds-accordion-item>
</sdds-accordion>

##### Introduction

In this section you will find answers to the most frequently asked questions about the Scania Digital Design System. FAQs address both [design](support/faqs/design) and [development](support/faqs/development) related questions (and answers) which are organised in separate sections. 

The FAQ section is updated on an ongoing basis, so please reach out to us if you have questions that you think should be included here.

<sdds-accordion>
  <sdds-accordion-item header="Is Scania Digital Design System accessible outside the Scania network?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Yes.
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Is Scania Digital Design System available on mobile platform?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Not at the moment. But we are working on it and we will make it available on mobile platforms in near future.
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Who works on the Scania Digital Design System?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    The Corporate Digital Design team (IXCD) works as the owners of Scania Digital Design System. The team collaborates with various teams across Scania as and when required.
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="I want to modify look and feel of a UI element. Is it possible?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Yes, it is possible but the modified UI element requires approval from the Scania Digital Design System governance team. There is a process in place for this purpose. For further information, please get in touch with Marcus Åstrom directly.
  </sdds-accordion-item>
</sdds-accordion>

section.Title: General
section.Text:
<sdds-accordion>
  <sdds-accordion-item header="What is SDDS theme and components?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    SDDS is a framework, based on StencilJS, which provide a UI toolbox to use in your application. All components are web-components and follow the web-component standard in the browser.
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="What is Theming?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Theme is a package built with CSS(SASS) to style every component according to Scania identity guidelines.
  </sdds-accordion-item>

<sdds-accordion-item header="What is a web-component?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

  Web-components are a standard for creating elements that you can use in your application. One standard component that is using the same technology is the <video></video> element. If you inspect the element with “shadow-dom show” enabled in your settings, you can see it is more to the eye than just a video element. Web-components usually consists of:

   - Custom elements
   - Shadow-DOM
   - HTML templates

  You can read more about it here: [Link](https://auth0.com/blog/creating-web-components-with-stencil/)

</sdds-accordion-item>

<sdds-accordion-item header="Is there any documentation or list of components?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

You can find the documentation of the components here: [Link](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components)

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Where do I find the Experimental components and patterns?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

We are planning to add all experimental components and pattern into Scania Digital Design System site later. Right now it is not possible to see component that is under development. You can check [design system repository](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds) to see our current backlog and components that are being developed in the moment.

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="What should I do if I find a component that isn’t accessible?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

 Contact our [team](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/support/contact)

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Where can I get help implementing the components with my project?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   Read how to use our components in the [getting started section](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/development)

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Why is SDDS so big?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

A very important part with Stencil is how the components are loaded, Stencil is built with
[self-lazy loading](https://stenciljs.com/docs/distribution).

   Only the components that are used via import, will be loaded into the application and only take that specific space in the memory.

   You just have to add one import for every component, instead of importing every individual component. The package size of both theme and SDDS will be improved to have smaller size.

   One of the reasons why it is so big is partly of the icon/pictogram solultion, which is something we are working on.

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Is there Dark mode in SDDS?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   Right now, no. But this is something that is highly demanded. The reason why we haven’t added is that it needs a lot for research before something like that can be implemented.

  </sdds-accordion-item>

<sdds-accordion-item header="I need a new icon, how do I add it?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

  - First, check if icon is available [here](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/foundation/icons)
  - Icon that has been included in Scania Media Provider but not available in SDDS: Create a [feature request](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds/issues/new/choose) with detail information about the icon that you need.
  - New icon: Contact our team for more information.

</sdds-accordion-item>

 <sdds-accordion-item header="Are there .psd or .sketch files of the components?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">Yes, you can find them here: [Link](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/resources/ui-kits)
 </sdds-accordion-item>

</sdds-accordion>

section.Title: What is supported
section.Text:
<sdds-accordion>
  <sdds-accordion-item header="Who can use the components?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Developers, with somewhat understanding of front-end development for all web based application.
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Which browsers are supported?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Chrome, Safari, Firefox and Edge
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="What JavaScript frameworks are supported?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Angular, React and Vue. More might come in the future.

   [See live examples](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/resources/development)

  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Can I use SDDS on third party application?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    Third part application has a very limited support, due to third-party applications is usually built differently. If you know how to import libraries and so on, please try it out!
  </sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="Why did you stop supporting font-awesome pro?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">
    We took the decision to start creating and using our own Scania icons. You can still use font-awesome pro, but you need to buy your own licence.
  </sdds-accordion-item>
</sdds-accordion>

section.Title: Migration
section.Text:
<sdds-accordion>
  <sdds-accordion-item header="Is it possible to migrate from Corporate-ui 3 or 4 to SDDS?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   Yes, it is! It will require some work. You can read more about it in our migration guide [link](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds/blob/master/MIGRATION.md). One thing to remember is that, not everything that was in Corporate-UI 3 and 4 will be in SDDS. We have removed and/or changed some components and dependencies that we had.

   You can see the biggest changes in the [getting started](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/overview/sdds-vs-corp-ui) section.

 </sdds-accordion-item>

<sdds-accordion-item header="What are the differences between version corporate-ui 3 and SDDS?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   One of the key things that changed are:

   - Moved from polymer to stencilJS
   - How you import a component
   - Removed bootstrap
   - Theming is added for styling components
   - Removed Font-awesome Pro support

    [Read migration guideline here](https://github.com/scania-digital-design-system/sdds/blob/master/MIGRATION.md)

</sdds-accordion-item>

  <sdds-accordion-item header="I haven’t updated to the latest version of Corporate UI yet, and I still need the old documentation. Where can I find it?" affix="prefix" tabindex="1">

   - [Visit documentation for Corporate UI 3](https://scania.github.io/corporate-ui-docs/)
   - [Visit documentation for Corporate UI 4](https://digitaldesign.devtest.aws.scania.com/home/)
  </sdds-accordion-item>
</sdds-accordion>

section.Title: Contribution
section.Text:

   - Structure: SDDS/components

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text:
For a strong and unified brand expression, Scania has developed a custom-made and unique font family — Scania Sans. Our typeface has a strong Scania DNA since it derives from our wordmark.

We use typography to present information and structure the entire user interface with clear hierarchy.

section.Title: Functional and Expressive
section.Text:
At Scania, we have divided our typography into two type sets, Functional and Expressive. These two types have different purposes, but there might be applications where a combination of them could be used. 

**Functional**
Should be used in non-branded communication, information and documentation. The main usage is for Scania applications (except apps used in-vehicle), where the typography’s focus is to help the user understand and perform tasks.

**Expressive**
Should be used for more branded external communication and public websites, for instance Scania.com. These types of applications need a much stronger expression for the typography, especially when it comes to headlines.

Learn more about each specific type set:

[Functional type](link)

[Expressive type](link)

section.Title: Images
section.Text:
Our colour palette for digital platforms consists of primary and secondary colours, which derives from our colours defined in our brand identity. We also have an extended palette that consists of a range of scales, which carefully and purposefully should be used as supporting colours and a number of semantic colours used strictly for UI CTAs and notifications such as alarm, warning, success and information.

**Sub section**
Our brand colours, blue and red, are derived from the Scania symbol and wordmark and effectively establish, represent and communicate the brand. Together with black and white they create our primary palette for digital applications.

LeadText.textfield: The notion of accessibility is about ensuring universal access to a website/application to all its intended users regardless of their disabilities or what software and hardware they use.

section.Title: Overview
section.Text:
Accessibility, in general, refers to the degree of usability of a website/application for users with various kinds of disabilities (e.g. visual, auditory, cognitive etc.). The notion of accessibility was proposed in pursuit of universal access to websites/applications regardless of any disability that a user might have due to their language or location or due to the software and hardware used by them. The objective of accessibility is not to exclude anyone from the use of any website/application that we develop. Accessibility design is considered as an important element of overall user experience of a website/application. W3C (World Wide Web Consortium) has formulated guidelines for accessibility design. Various countries, such as Sweden have also proposed their own accessibility guidelines. In many cases, accessibility of website/application is mandatory by law of the land (e.g. USA). The W3C provides information on the following aspects to help us get started: 1. Guidelines for UI and visual design
2. Guidelines for development ##### Accessibility Principles In addition to this, the W3C also provides good guidance on the Principles of Accessibility. It is recommended that such principles should be followed when designing for accessibility. ##### How do we know a website/application is accessibility compliant? The W3C also provides a guide to carry out checks for accessibility, see here.

section.Title: Implementing accessibility
section.Text:
The team working with the Scania Digital Design System is committed to the principles of universal accessibility of websites and applications developed at Scania. The principles of accessibility design have been applied for the design of the website of the Scania Digital Design System, which makes it accessibility compliant. 

Moreover, accessibility compliant design elements from the Scania Digital Design System are designed to build accessibility ground up as and when such elements are applied for design and development of Scania website/applications. 

Please reach out to the team should you need any advice on accessibility design and implementation.

LeadText.textfield: Below you will find a comprehensive list of useful Scania Manuals and Guidelines.

section.Text:
##### Scania Identity Manual

The Scania brand identity has been designed to unite and modernise the brand expression and to support the desired brand image. Our visual identity is defined in the Scania Identity Manual and needs to be used by following the defined rules within this document.

##### Mobile Application Styleguide (Appendix)

To ensure a strong unified global brand identity and experience, principles for applying the Scania brand assets in mobile applications have been developed. This appendix is part of the Scania Identity Manual.

LeadText.textfield: The logotype is an important graphic identifier. It creates brand recognition in all our applications, but also recognition and coherence across different digital applications.

section.Title: Resources
section.Text:
Our logotype is one of our primary assets, our strongest branding tools which can be used across all channels at all times. More information about the logotype and other brand assets is available in the [Scania Identity manual](resources/brand/manuals). 

The logotype consists of 3 different versions.

**Wordmark**
Unique and distinct, the wordmark – Scania – is the most direct and effective asset in communicating the brand. It’s used in the header and may also be repeated in the footer, but never in body text. 

**Symbol**
The symbol with the eye-catching griffin at the centre, conveys quality and robustness and is always placed in the header. 

**Lock-up logotype**
Our wordmark and symbol together form a lock-up logotype. It’s a fixed asset, available in a vertical and horizontal version.

More detailed information about how the logotype versions are used and placed will be available in the patterns section (header and footer) in Q2.

LeadText.textfield: Images and films are efficient tools for telling our stories at Scania, to provide useful information and to create more inspirational and rich experiences.

section.Text:
##### Resources
At Scania Media Provider, you will get access to an extensive image and film archive. Visit the website, log in with your Scania/XDS account and start browsing for the imagery that you need.

LeadText.textfield: Scania’s pictogram family helps us to organise and categorise information. Speaking the universal language of symbols, our icons facilitate the encounter with the Scania brand. They create a unified and uncluttered experience in every channel.

section.Text:
#### Resources

You can download all our pictograms below. If you are looking for a specific one, please browse our [Pictogram Library](foundations/pictograms/pictograms). If you need a pictogram, please check thoroughly in our pictogram library if you could use any of the already existing ones. Should the needed pictogram not exist, you may create a new pictogram following our [guidelines](foundations/pictograms/contribute).

LeadText.textfield: This section offers a number of resources for designers, developers and others who might be interested in the process of design and development of digital design solutions at Scania.

It offers high level resources, such as definitions and way of working for design and development teams, as well as downloadable resources, such as UI design kit and various resources for development.

section.Title: Scania Privacy Statement
section.Text:
A core value for us at Scania is Respect for the individual. This is the foundation when we interact with you in your role as a user of Scania Digital Design System.

The data controller responsible for your personal data is Scania CV AB, unless otherwise stated in a privacy statement specific to a service as accessible through digitaldesign.scania.com

We process your personal data when it is needed to:

- deliver our services,
- support and assist you when you use our services,
- fulfil legal obligations and legitimate requests from law enforcement and other authorities,
- provide information about our products and services as well as upcoming events,
- improve quality and develop existing, as well as new,  products and  services as well as our organization.

We strive to always handle and protect your personal data with respect and integrity. Sometimes we utilize trusted business partners to help us deliver our products and services. In those cases when we need to share your data with our business partners, we ensure that they treat your data with the same respect and integrity that we do.

In this privacy statement we would like to inform you what personal data we might process, why we are doing it and how we ensure that your rights and your privacy is respected. If you have any questions or concerns you are always welcome to [contact us](https://www.scania.com/global/en/home/misc/privacy-statement/contact-privacy.html).

LeadText.textfield: Without using words, colours tell the story of a brand. Colours convey an immediate and lasting impression, which is why the brand colour palette is of crucial importance.

section.Title: Colours
section.Text:
In order to answer digital environment needs and constraints, we have broadened Scania brand colour core palette with additional semantic colours as well as extended colour scales.

More information regarding Scania Brand Colour Palette will be available soon on Scania Brand Portal.

##### Brand palette
Our primary brand colour, Scania Blue, is derived from the Scania symbol and wordmark, and effectively establishes, represents and communicates the brand DNA. Together with black and white they create our brand palette for digital applications.

##### Semantic colours
Semantic colours communicate important status to the user such as success, information, warning or error. They essentially have a functional purpose, therefore they shouldn’t be used as decoration or as a background colour on large surfaces. 

These colours should be used paired with text, an icon or both to fulfill their purpose in the best way possible.

##### Scales
In addition to our brand palette and semantic colours, we have defined extended colour scales of blue and red. These scales enable us to create strong and clear colour hierarchies within our applications, as well as visualising different states of our interactive UI components such as CTA. You can find more information on how to apply these scales to CTA on the [Buttons](components/buttons) component page.

Image.caption: Find all scales on the Specifications tab

section.Text:
##### Background colours
In order to allow Scania applications to live on both light and dark theme, we have defined a grey scale used for the different background colours elevations.

Image.caption: Find all scales on the Specifications tab

section.Title: Themes
section.Text: All Scania applications can live on two main different themes: a light theme and a dark theme. These themes serve as the foundation for colours and should be selected carefully depending on their usage and for whom the interfaces are designed for.

Image.caption: Each theme has two variants. These variants define the lower level colour value applicable on which the elevation principle will apply (more information below).

section.Text:
Theme Theme variant Background colour HEX value
$light-theme $on-white $white #FFFFFF
$light-theme $on-grey-50 $grey-50 #F9FAFB
$dark-theme $on-grey-958 $grey-958 #0D0F13
$dark-theme $on-grey-900 $grey-900 #1D2229
##### Light theme This theme is the standard choice for Expressive applications, where we need to have a dynamic and rich brand experience. It is also the standard choice for our Functional applications, where the user is mainly active in a work place with natural lightning.

##### Dark theme
The dark theme is a low-light UI which uses our darker colours from the greyscale as a primary background colours. In general, we use more desaturated colours since colours with high saturation tend to vibrate on dark backgrounds. 

A dark framework helps to reduce eye-strain for our users, especially when they are using our applications during night time or in a low-light environment. It also has a sustainable approach, since it conserves battery life for devices with OLED screens. This theme is mainly used for our Functional applications.

The choice between dark and light theme can also be left to the user’s preference including a toggle switch functionality in the application.

Images.caption: The values from $white to $grey-500 are used for surfaces on light theme. The values from $grey-958 to $grey-600 are used for surfaces on dark theme.
Surface colours according to the elevation level on light theme
Depth can be visually translated by the use of lighter surface colours at higher levels of elevation.

section.Title: Legibility
section.Text:
At Scania we value accessibility and consider it as an important element of an overall user experience within our applications. Our texts and links should be legible and meet [The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG 2.0) level AA](https://www.w3.org/WAI/standards-guidelines/wcag/), which requires a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 for normal text, and 3:1 to large text.

Our colours have a scale which consists of 10 values (black and white excluded). On backgrounds using darker values, white text is accessible and on backgrounds using lighter values, dark text is accessible.

Learn more about our thoughts on [Accessibility](foundations/accessibility) design.

section.Title: Colour typography
section.Text: Our typography hierarchy treatment is highlighted by the use of an opacity system on light and dark themes to ensure enough legibility.

section.Title: Colour tokens
section.Text:
In our Unit System, we are using tokens to manage our variables, and this is to be able to go away from having hard coded values to ensure consistency in our UIs. It also makes it more efficient to implement, maintain and update.

We are using the same approach for our colour palettes. For instance, instead of coding all instances when using our blue colour with #041E42, we can instead apply a token like $blue-800.
##### Colour specification Below you can find a detailed list of all official Scania colours. Note, these are also available in Github,as ASE and within our UI Kit.

section.Title: Usage

LeadText.textfield: Language is not just what we say, but how we say it. Scania’s tone of voice is honest, sincere, respectful and confident. Typography is the visualisation of our voice.

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text:
For a strong and unified brand expression, Scania has developed a custom-made and unique font family — Scania Sans. Our typeface has a strong Scania DNA since it derives from our wordmark.

We use typography to present information and structure the entire user interface with clear hierarchy.

section.Title: Functional & Expressive
section.Text:
At Scania, we have divided our typography into two type sets, Functional and Expressive. These two types have different purposes, but there might be applications where a combination of them could be used. **Functional** Should be used in non-branded communication, information and documentation. The main usage is for Scania applications (except apps used in-vehicle), where the typography’s focus is to help the user understand and perform tasks. **Expressive** Should be used for more branded external communication and public websites, for instance Scania.com. These types of applications need a much stronger expression for the typography, especially when it comes to headlines. Learn more about each specific type set:
[Functional type](foundations/foundation-typography/functional-type)
[Expressive type](foundations/foundation-typography/expressive-type)

section.Title: Typeface
section.Text:
The Scania Sans typeface family has several fonts and weights, making it ideal for every context and every occasion, from bold and inspiring headlines to informative footnotes.. The typeface family has four fonts:
— Scania Sans Headline
— Scania Sans
— Scania Sans Semi Condensed
— Scania Sans Condensed

section.Title: Type settings
section.Text:
We use four type settings when applying typography within our user interfaces. These type settings have several text styles that could be found at [Functional type](foundation/foundation-typography/functional-type) and [Expressive type](foundation/foundation-typography/expressive-type).

**Headline**
Used to create clear typographic hierarchies.

**Paragraph**
Use for introduction texts.

**Body**
Used primarily for longer body texts, intro texts and specific components. 

**Detail**
Used for captions, detailed text, table, component and code related typography.

section.Title: Type scale
section.Text:
When designing and creating new layouts and applications, you should use any of our defined type sets Functional or Expressive, depending on what you’re designing for. This scale will help you create consistent layouts with a balanced rhythm.

In some specific scenarios, you might end up needing a size that is not specified within those type sets. When adding a new text style, you should select a size from our type scale below to get a cohesive typographic experience.

Rem Pixel Example
2.5 10 Scania Sans Regular
3 12 Scania Sans Regular
3.5 14 Scania Sans Regular
4 16 Scania Sans Regular
5 20 Scania Sans Regular
6 24 Scania Sans Regular
7 28 Scania Sans Regular
8 32 Scania Sans Regular
10 40 Scania Sans Regular
12 48 Scania Sans Regular
14 56 Scania Sans Regular
16 64 Scania Sans Regular
18 72 Scania Sans Regular
20 80 Scania Sans Regular

section.Title: Tokens
section.Text:
For managing our typography, we use tokens that have defined all our typographic settings such as font size, font weight, letter height and letter spacing. These tokens should be used when designing a new page layout or application.

Visit [Functional type](foundation/foundation-typography/functional-type) and [Expressive type](foundation/foundation-typography/expressive-type) to get a full overview of which tokens that are available within each type set.

section.Title: Fallback
section.Text:
When Scania Sans fail to load due to technical issues or when technical restrictions or special glyphs for languages limits the use of Scania Sans typeface, the following replacement fonts – or similar - are recommended:

**Mac computers**
Helvetica Neue

**PC computers**
Arial

section.Title: Functional type
section.Text:
The Functional type set should be used for non-branded communication, information and documentation. The main usage is for Scania applications (except apps used in-vehicle), where the typography’s focus is to help the user understand and perform tasks.

The text styles are available below. If you need more sizes, please select a size from our [type scale](foundations/foundation-typography/information#type-scale) when defining a new text style for your project.

LeadText.textfield: Scania Digital Design System's typography package will help you implement the official typography properties in your application in an easy way.

section.Title: Installation
section.Text: If you already install '@scania/theme-light' you can use the CSS classes directly in your HTML. If you need the SCSS functions, you can install SDDS typography package with npm. Run the following command:

section.code: > npm i @scania/typography --save

section.Title: Using tokens
Using Compiled CSS
section.Text: You can also import the CSS file to directly use all the classes. It will also import Scania webfont. When you import the CSS file, it is possible to use it without '@scania/theme-light' and without 'sdds-theme' component. Below is an example how to use it.

section.Title: Fonts via CDN
section.Text:
As an alternative from the solution above, you can also import the fonts directly into your application via CDN. Remember, if you already installed @scania/theme-light in your application, you do not need to import the CSS again. If you need the fonts without the theme, the CSS is available on this URL:

https://cdn.digitaldesign.scania.com/fonts/scania-sans/1.0.0/scania-sans.css

The Scania brand identity has been designed to unite and modernise the brand expression and to support the desired brand image. Our visual identity is defined in the Scania Identity Manual and needs to be used by following the defined rules within this document.

LeadText.textfield: Welcome to SDDS, Scania Digital Design System for products and digital experiences!

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text:
The design system supports the design and development of digital solutions at Scania. The purpose is to secure a coherent and premium brand and user experience across all of Scania's digital touchpoints.

The main pillars of our Design System are the following:

**Foundations**
A resource for principles and styleguide that are considered as the foundations for conceptualization of digital design solutions. 

**Components**
Our smaller, yet important, interactive building blocks of the design system. These should be used when creating a new digital solution.

**Patterns**
Patterns usually consist of multiple components that handle common user objectives and occurring problems. They could be seen as best practices and general solutions for how our users achieves a goal inside our applications.

**Resources**
A collection of knowledge assets, tools and downloadable assets to help our designers and developers when creating new digital solutions.

section.Title: Contribute
section.Text:
Scanias Digital Design System is an active organism, constantly evolving and adopting to meet the demands of our users. Therefore we strongly encourage and welcome contributions from the whole organisation. Together, we can update and make SDDS a better design system.

Feel free to reach out to us if you want to request a feature or propose a new design.

LeadText.textfield: Tooltips display an explanatory text when the user either hovers, focuses or clicks an element.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
A tooltip should inform the users by showing a text about the specific element that the user is interacting with. For instance, it could clarify the action of a specific icon button within a navigation pattern. 

It appears when the user either hovers over, focuses or taps/clicks it. The text of the tooltip should always be clear and concise. It is always placed on a background contrasting with the surface it appears on, and it is always placed close to the specific element it is connected to.

section.Title: Placement
section.Text:
Tooltips are always positioned top or bottom of the element. It should never obstruct the element and it always needs to be clearly visible. The exact position of the tooltip depends on the context. It may be positioned left, right or centre.

When an element is located in the outer edges of the screen, eg top left, right or bottom, the tooltip should be displayed where screen space is available.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text: The tooltip contains two mandatory elements; text and container. The text describes the specific element that the user interacts with.

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for tooltip.

**No imagery in tooltips**

Don’t use images or videos inside a tooltip, it should only contain text.

dosAndDonts.description: Only use text inside a tooltip
Add an image inside a tooltip

section.Text:
**Don’t  restate text**

Make sure not to use tooltip for restating a buttons text. Tooltips shouldn’t be used for scenarios like this.

dosAndDonts.description: Restate visible text

section.Title: Colour
section.Text: The tooltip only has one default state.

Element Colour
Text $white
Container $grey-600

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text: The toggle is only available in one size where the width vary depending on the text. In general, the tooltips text is placed one row consisting of 1 to 4 words. However, in certain scenarios we might need to use a sentence place on multiple rows. When using a sentence the height will also vary in size.

Text Width px / rem Height px / rem
One row Width varies 32 / 8
Multiple rows Max. 208 / 52 Height varies
**One row**
**Multiple rows**

section.Title: Typography
section.Text:
Text Text Style
Default $detail-05

section.Title: Corner radius
section.Text:
Our tooltip has as default rounded corners with a 4px / 1rem corner radius. When the tooltip is connected to an element that is located in the outer edges of the screen, e.g. top or bottom left/right, one of the corners is square. 

The square is a subtle visualisation of an arrow, and the corner that is squared is aligned with the position of the tooltip. For instance, if the tooltip is positioned to the left, the corner that is square is the top left one.

Corner style Corner radius
Rounded 4 px / 1 rem
Square 0 px / 0 rem

LeadText.textfield: An accordion is a component that can be collapsed and expanded, used to reveal or hide additional content.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
Use accordions when you want to give the user a quick and clear overview of information that is available. It is great to use when there is a need for presentation of information on a number of topics in a limited space, since it saves vertical space and reduces scrolling.

By using accordions, you can hide information with lower priority and also let the user decide what information they want to see. The additional information that is hidden, gets revealed when the user clicks/taps the accordion

The accordion can be used on its own or grouped in multiples, creating a stacked vertical list of accordions.

section.Title: Placement
section.Text: Accordions can be placed in your main content area or inside other components or patterns, such as data tables or a left navigation. Depending on where the accordion is placed, the visual style may vary to be able to fit in the specific placement. An accordion should however always follow the same functional logic regarding expand and collapse, and contain it’s mandatory elements; header, icon & panel.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
The accordion contains three mandatory elements; header, icon and panel. 

The header gives users the context about the additional information available inside the panel. It could either be stated as a headline or a question when used in a FAQ. The icon describes the state of the accordion, if the panel is expanded or collapsed. The panel is displayed below the header and contains the additional content.

In the basic accordion, dividers are needed to separate and contain the accordions. In certain scenarios, the dividers can be removed. For instance when an accordion is used on its own inside a data table, the dividers are not needed.

Image.caption:
A. Header
B. Icon
C. Panel
D. Divider (optional)

section.Text:
##### Prefix and Suffix icon

As default, we use suffix icon in our accordion, but there is an option to use prefix instead depending on the context of the accordion location. 

For instance, when using accordion in a complex data table with a lot of rows and columns, we recommend to use the prefix icon to make it easier and quicker for the user to decode that certain rows are expandable.

section.Title: States
section.Text:
An accordion can either be collapsed or expanded. The icon arrow’s direction describes which state the accordion is in, where points up is expanded and points down collapsed. 

As default, the accordion is always collapsed to maximize the overview for the user. If needed, there is an option to allow the first accordion expanded as well.

They also have different states to communicate the accordions different status for our users. These states are enabled, hover, focus, pressed and disabled. The entire accordion, not only the header or icon, is interactive.

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for accordions.

##### Icon direction
The icon should change direction depending if the accordion is expanded or collapsed.

dosAndDonts.description: Point the icon down when collapsed
Point the icon down when expanded

section.Text:
##### Don’t nest accordions

When grouping accordions, they should be stacked vertically in a list and not nested. Never put an accordion inside another accordion.

dosAndDonts.description: Stack accordions vertically
Nest accordions

section.Title: Colour
section.Text:
Accordions come in two sets of colours. Depending on what theme or background colour the accordion exists on, the colour of the accordions state focus varies.

The accordion has no container colour as default, and the colour of the container will only be applied when the state is either hover or focused.

When placed $on-white content background, the hover and focus state switches the container colour to $grey-50. When placed $on-grey content background, the container switches to $white when the state is hover or focused.

Note, more additional information about theming will be released later this year.

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text:
The basic accordion is available in one size, where the width varies depending on where it is located, in the main content area or inside a component. The height is fixed when the accordion is collapsed, and it varies when the accordion is expanded.

When accordions are vertically stacked, the bottom divider should disappear to avoid multiple dividers in a row.

section.tableHtml:

Collapsed Width varies 48 / 12 16x16
Expanded Width varies Height varies 16x16

LeadText.textfield: A dropdown presents a list of options to the user, and allows them to choose one or more to take action.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: Dropdowns can be used to represent a value in a form, as well as to filter or sort content. They can be used in a wide context, spanning from full page layouts, modals and components like data tables. The items they contain are usually sorted by the priority of their usage.

section.Title: Types
section.Text: There are four types of dropdowns that cater for different needs; default, multi-select, filter and nested dropdown.

**Default dropdown**

The default dropdown should be used when one selection between a limited number of items needs to be made. The dropdown automatically collapses when the user has pressed one of the items in the list.

**Multi-select dropdown**

Sometimes users need to select more than one item in a dropdown menu, and that is the case when the multi-select dropdown should be used. The main difference compared to the default dropdown is that a checkbox appears on the left side of each dropdown items, as well as the fact that the dropdown does not collapse automatically when the user selects an item. The user needs to manually close the dropdown when they are done with their selections by either clicking on the dropdown or outside the dropdown.

**Filter dropdown**

The filter dropdown is the preferable way when the users needs to make a selection from a very long list, thus making the use of a simple dropdown cumbersome. In this variation, users can start typing right when they have clicked on the dropdown. Filter can be used on all dropdown types.

**Nested dropdown**

Sometimes, having a single list of items in the dropdown is not enough. That is when a nested dropdown can come handy, by giving the possibility to group items into categories, which adds one extra hierarchy level. However this type should be used in moderation, only when it’s truly necessary.

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text: There are four different dropdown sizes: large, medium and small, where large is our primary dropdown size.

section.Title: States
section.Text: A dropdown can either be collapsed or expanded. The icon arrow’s direction describes which state the dropdown is in, where points up is expanded and points down collapsed. As default, the dropdown is always collapsed.

They also have different states, for both collapsed and expanded, to communicate the dropdowns different status for our users.

**Collapsed**
**Expanded**

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
The dropdown always contain the following elements; a text label, container, icon, option container and divider.

For a multi-select dropdown, the component checkbox is also added as a mandatory element.

Images.label: Collapsed
Images.caption:
A. Text label
B. Container
C. Icon

Images.label: Expanded (Default)
Images.caption:
D. Option text
E. Option container
F. Divider

section.Text:
**Label text**

The label text will help us to describe to the users what the dropdown contains and all of our dropdown types also have variations on how the label text could be used; label inside, no label and label outside. 

You should select dropdown variation based on which context the dropdown will be placed in and what works best with the applications design you are working with in general. 

For instance, the label inside works well for more narrow spaces and label outside is a good option for forms with a lot of dropdowns present, making it easier for the users to decode the information. When using label outside, you still need to have a dropdown text present. Note, for our smallest size ‘Small’, you can not use label-inside due to size limitations.

No label is a good choice when adding a dropdown inside a data table, where a label will be present in the column head instead.  

Make sure to keep the label text short and concised.

**Helper text**

Helper text assists the user with additional information text about the dropdown and to act as an error message.

section.Title: Do’s and Dont’s
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for dropdowns.

**Scrollbar**

It’s important that an expanded dropdown doesn’t list too many options at once. Use a scrollbar to limit the amount of items shown to the user. A rule of thumb is to never list more than 5-7 options at a time. With that said, it is up to each designer to make the decision depending on the context of the dropdown.

dosAndDonts.description: Use a scroll bar for dropdowns with more than 7 options
List more than 7 options without a scroll bar

section.Title: Colour
section.Text: Our dropdowns come in different types and a set of states. The types have the same styling, with some additional elements added depending on state. These additional elments are specified for each type. The container is using the same shadow-settings used on our cards.

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text:
A dropdown contains a lot of elements in combination with a container. Depending on the dropdown size, the spacing to its elements varies inside the dropdown.

The sizes are large, medium, and small, where large is our primary dropdown size. 

The width of the dropdown varies, since it should align with the context and layout where it is placed. We have a recommended minimum width, but there might be specific scenarios where you need to have a smaller width, and therefor it is possible to remove.

section.Title: Filter
section.Text:
To add filter functionality, you can use 'sdds-dropdown-filter'. You need to add the options through the 'data' attribute. 
The data is an array of objects that contains 2 values: 'value' and 'label'. There are 2 ways of adding the data. You can add it as a string value directly, or append the data in the script. The second way is more recommended.

section.title: Add data as a string
section.code:
<sdds-dropdown-filter 
  placeholder="Select option"
  data='[{"value":"opt-1","label":"Jakarta"},{"value":"opt-2","label":"Stockholm"},{"value":"opt-3","label":"Barcelona"}]'>
</sdds-dropdown-filter>

section.title: Add data via script
section.code:
<sdds-dropdown-filter
  id="myFilter" 
  placeholder="Select option">
</sdds-dropdown-filter>

<script>
var data= [
        {"value":"opt-1","label":"Jakarta"},
        {"value":"opt-2","label":"Stockholm"},
        {"value":"opt-3","label":"Barcelona"}
    ];
var dropdown = document.querySelector('#myFilter');
dropdown.data = data;
</script>

section.Title: Event Handler
section.Text:
There are 2 available events from the components that can be used to fetch the selected options and catch the search term.

##### selectOption

The event is triggered everytime an option is being clicked. It will return the option value, option label, and parent node.

##### inputSearch

This event is available on dropdown with search function. This event is triggered every time the text field input is being clicked or being focused during the typing action. It will return an input text event, which can be used to fetch the input text value at the moment.

See example below on how to use the events.

If you use a class called `sdds-on-white-bg` on either container level or on the component it self, the css variables have different values that will match with the white background.

If you want full-styling for your dropdown, you can use sdds-dropdown web components, and use the available events to mimic native form. (See React and Angular example).

LeadText.textfield: Spacing is just as important as the Unit and Grid System. It helps us to create a harmonious layout, with both vertical and horizontal rhythm.

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text:
By having clear spacing scales, we limit the layout to make use of only a specific number of units instead of using a wide span of various spacing options which quickly escalates and creates an inconsistent experience. We also make sure that we are consistent across our entire components library.

At Scania, we use two spacing scales which both are based on our Unit System; layout scale and element scale. Both the scales are applicable on vertical and horizontal edges.

section.Title: Layout scale
section.Text:
The layout scale is used when we position content, components and patterns on a page layout. This scale should always be used when creating new layouts. 

Should an application need an additional spacing size, make sure to use our Unit System as base to create a consistent spacing scale when creating a new token.

Rem Pixel Token Scale
2 8 $spacing-layout-8
4 16 $spacing-layout-16
6 24 $spacing-layout-24
8 32 $spacing-layout-32
12 48 $spacing-layout-48
16 64 $spacing-layout-64
24 96 $spacing-layout-96
32 128 $spacing-layout-128
40 160 $spacing-layout-160

section.Title: Element scale
section.Text:
The element scale is used when building components where we need smaller units to work with, when defining all detailed work within a component. Should a component need an additional spacing size, make sure to use our Unit System as base to create a consistent spacing scale, when creating a new token.
Rem Pixel Token Scale
0.5 2 $spacing-element-2
1 4 $spacing-element-4
2 8 $spacing-element-8
3 12 $spacing-element-12
4 16 $spacing-element-16
5 20 $spacing-element-20
6 24 $spacing-element-24
8 32 $spacing-element-32
10 40 $spacing-element-40
12 48 $spacing-element-48

section.Title: Exceptions
section.Text:
There are exceptions within Scania user interfaces where we don’t use our spacing element token for spacing elements.

**Centre**
This is used when we contextually need to centre an element between two edges, for instance a text within a specific button component.

Image.label: Center alignment
Image.caption: Text in a full bleed button

LeadText.textfield: Scania Digital Design System's spacing package will help you implement spacing tokens in your application in an easy way.

section.Title: Installation
section.Text: Spacing package is included in '@scania/theme-light' and '@scania/grid' package. If you have installed one of them, you are good to go. If you have not install theme or grid, you can install it using the guidelines from this page: [Getting started development](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/getting-started/development/installation).
