LeadText.textfield: Buttons are clickable elements that trigger events or actions. They communicate actions to the users and allow them to interact with pages in a variety of ways.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
Buttons inform the users of possible actions they can take within an application. They can be used throughout different places in your layout, for example: dialogs, modals, forms, cards and toolbars.

The text label is used to inform the user which action that will occur when the user interacts with it.

section.Title: Types
section.Text: There are four types of buttons with different purpose and hierarchy in order to help the user to distinguish the level of importance of the task they represent. These types are primary, secondary, ghost and danger.

Type Usage
Primary High emphasis button used to attract attention to the most important task of the layout. Should be used sparsely within the layout to avoid confusion of which button is the primary action.
Secondary Medium emphasis button used for alternative non-primary actions. Should be used together with a primary button to show a second alternative for a user faced with a choice between two actions.
Ghost Low emphasis button used for less important actions. Usually used in combination with a primary button. Should not be mixed up with or used instead of a link.
Danger Could be used as a final confirmation for a destructive action such as deleting. Mostly used in confirmation modals.

section.Title: States
section.Text: Buttons have different states to communicate the buttons different status for our users.

Images.label: Focused
Images.caption: Highlighted by keyboard or voice
Images.alternate: Focused Highlighted by keyboard or voice

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text: There are four different button sizes: default, medium, small and full bleed where default is our primary button size.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
A button contains at least two elements; a text label, an icon or both in combination with a container. The text label and icon can be used in combination to improve the clarity of the buttons action.

The icon button should only be used for simple and well known actions like download, remove, expand, collapse.

Images.label: Text+icon button
Images.caption:
A. Text label
B. Container
C. Icon

section.Title: Do’s and Dont’s
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for buttons.

##### Short text labels
Text labels should be short and direct, since it needs to be easy to read what action the button will perform when the user interacts with it.

dosAndDonts.description: Short and direct text labels
Long and complicated text labels

section.Text:
##### One line text labels
To secure good legibility, a text label should be placed on one line and not be wrapped on multiple lines. If you have narrowed width space to place your button, move it below the associated content.

dosAndDonts.description: Text on a single line
Text on multiple lines

section.Text:
##### One primary button
We need to help the user to understand which action is more important by only having one primary button present at the time on the section.

dosAndDonts.description: One primary button present
Two primary buttons present

section.Text:
Our buttons come in four different types and a set of states. The types along with the states vary in colour. ##### Container

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text:
A button contains at least two elements; a text label, an icon or both in combination with a container. Depending on the button size, the spacing inside the button to its elements varies. When a button is using a text label, the width of the button varies based on text labels length. A full bleed button works differently. Instead of growing with the text labels length, it bleeds to the edges of the component or pattern its placed in.

section.Title: Typography
section.Text:
The text label inside a button should start with the first letter set in upper case, and the remaining letters in lower case. For all of our button types and sizes, we are usign the same typography.

LeadText.textfield: Checkbox is a component that allows the user to select one or several items from a list when there are multiple options.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: Checkboxes should be used to inform the user that they can select one or several options from a range of options. The user should always be able to regret a choice, hence they should be able to unselect a checkbox after selecting one.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
Checkboxes have three different types. They can either be arranged in a list with multiple choices, in a list with a parent-child relation or be a standalone element within another component.

##### Multiple choice list 
The checkboxes could be arranged in both a vertical and horizontal list. Select one of them based on which context it will be placed in and the structure of the user interface you are working with. Have in mind that vertical lists are easier to read than horizontal ones.

##### Parent-child list
When needed we can also group checkboxes to create a parent and child relationship. This gives the user the possibility to select all checkboxes in the group in only one click.

When the parent checkbox is selected, all child checkboxes are selected. If it unselected, all child checkboxes are unselected. And if some of the child checkboxes are selected, the parent checkbox becomes an indeterminate checkbox.

##### Standalone
The standalone checkbox should be used in combination with other components, for instance as a select element inside a card.

section.Title: States
section.Text:
Checkboxes can either be selected, unselected or indeterminate. Indeterminate is used to communicate when there is a sublist of selections with both selected and unselected options.

They have also different states to communicate the different status for our users. These states are disabled, enabled, hover and focused.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
A checkbox contains two mandatory elements; label text, checkbox input and select marker. The checkbox input together with the select marker shows the checkbox current state, which default state is unselected. The label text describes for the user what option that can be selected or unselected. 

It could also contain a fourth optional element; headline, which could be used to clarify the different selection options that are available.

The checkbox input should always be positioned to the left followed by the lable text.

Images.label: Checkbox
Images.caption:
A. Headline (optional)
B. Select marker
C. Checkbox input
D. Label text

section.Text:
##### Parent-child list
The parent-child list have one more additional element and that is the parent checkbox input which is placed above the child checkboxes.

Image.label: Parent-child
Image.caption:
A. Parent checkbox input
B. Child checkbox input

section.Text:
##### Multiple lines
We recommend that text labels always should be short, just containing a few words. If there is a scenario where there is a need to use longer label texts, we can wrap the text on multiple lines if the checkbox list is placed within a narrowed space.

section.Title: Do's and Dont's
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for checkboxes.

##### One option selection

Checkboxes are not suitable for scenarios where a user should be limited to select a singel option. For a scenario like this, radio button is the component to use.

dosAndDonts.description: Use radio button for one option selection
Use checkbox for one option selection

section.Text:
##### Text alignment

When you are using long label texts that wraps to multiple lines, the label text need to be top aligned to maintain consistency.

dosAndDonts.description: Top align the text label
Center align the text label

section.Title: Colour
section.Text: Our checkbox comes in different set of states, and the states vary in colours.

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text: The checkbox is available in one size.

section.Title: Typography
section.Text: The label text and headline should start with the first letter set in upper case, and the remaining letters in lower case.

section.Title: Corner radius
section.Text: The checkbox has rounded corners with a 2px / 0.5 rem corner radius.

section.tableHtml:
Corner radius Corners
2 px / 0.5 rem Top, bottom, left and right

LeadText.textfield: A divider is a 1px line that help us group and separate content within our layouts, components and patterns.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
Dividers help us both to group and to separate content. We use dividers within our page layouts and also within our components and patterns.

They should be used sparingly and only if we can’t separate content using white space. Too many dividers present on a small surface will be perceived as a cluttered and busy experience.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
We have two different types of dividers, full-bleed dividers and indent dividers. Each type has a horizontal and vertical version.

##### Full-bleed dividers
Full-bleed dividers are as the name describes, full-bleed components. This means that a full-bleed divider is aligned with the margins of the component or the page.

This type of dividers is used to separate different sections within a layout, to separate unrelated texts inside lists (for instance a data table) and to separate content inside a header for instance.

##### Indent dividers

The opposite to full-bleed dividers is our indent dividers. They have the same visual appearance and what separates them is that these do not behave as a full-bleed component. Indent dividers are used to separate related content, inside lists or data tables for instance.

Images.label: Indent divider
Images.caption: Vertical example used in a sub headline

section.Title: Colour
section.Text:
Dividers come in different colours. Depending on what theme or background colour the divider exists on, the colour of the divider varies.

On our lightest backgrounds, the colour of the divider will be the next step above the background colour. For instance, $white background equals $grey-100 divider and $grey-100 background equals $grey-200 divider. 

On background colours with 300 or higher, colour of the divider will be the next step below the background colour. For instance, $grey-300 background equals $grey-200 divider.

The exception is when we reach the highest step within a colour, 900. Then we will use 700 as divider colour to make sure that we have a good contrast between the divider and the background.

##### Examples
Background Divider colour
$white $grey-100
$grey-100 $grey-200
$grey-200 $grey-300
$grey-300 $grey-200
$grey-400 $grey-300
$grey-500 $grey-400
$grey-600 $grey-500
$grey-700 $grey-600
$grey-800 $grey-700
$grey-900 $grey-700

section.Title: Specs
section.Text: Our dividers, both full-bleed and indents, have a width of 1 px / 0.25 rem.

Image.caption: The dividers are 1px / 0.25 rem thick.

LeadText.textfield: Radio button is a component that allows the user to select only one single option from a list when there are multiple options.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: Radio buttons should be used to inform the user that they can only select one single option from a list with all the available options presented.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
Radio buttons are arranged in a list form, supported by a parent label. The radio buttons could be arranged in both a vertical and horizontal list. Select one of them based on which context it will be placed in and the structure of the user interface you are working with. 
Have in mind that vertical lists are easier to read than horizontal ones.

Image.caption: Horizontal list
Vertical list

section.Title: States
section.Text: Radio buttons can either be selected or unselected. They also have different states to communicate the checkboxes different status for our users. These states are disabled, enabled, hover and focused.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
A radio button contains three mandatory elements; radio button input, label text and select marker. The radio button input together with the select marker shows the radio buttons current state, which default state is unselected. The label text describes for the user what option that can be selected or unselected.

It could also contain a fourth optional element; headline, which could be used to clarify the  selection options that are available.

The radio button input should always be positioned to the left followed by the label text.

Image.label: Radio button
Image.caption:
A. Headline (optional)
B. Select marker
C. Radio button input
D. Label text

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for radio buttons.

##### Pre selected option
Avoid having all options unselected. Make sure to always have a pre selected option and let the user decide another option instead.

dosAndDonts.description: Pre selected option
Unselected options

section.Text:
##### One option selection
Make sure to use radio buttons instead of checkboxes when the user only have one option that could be selected.

dosAndDonts.description: Use radio button for one option selection
Use checkbox for one option selection

section.Text:
##### Radio button vs Toggle
Avoid using radio buttons when the choice is to switch between an On / Off state. For scenarios like this, consider to use a [toggle](/components/toggle) instead.

dosAndDonts.description: Use toggle for On/Off
Use radio button for On/Off

section.Title: Colour
section.Text: Our radio button comes in different set of states, and the states vary in colours.

LeadText.textfield: A text field is a component that facilitates entry and editing of text. In general text fields are used to collect and post subsequently information provided by users.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: Text fields are used as an integral part of a form (of various kinds) to enable users to edit and post text. Text fields should be legible so that users know where to enter the text. In addition to this, text fields should clearly show its state to convey when text can or cannot be entered.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
Text fields have three different types; label inside, label outside and no label.

You should select text field type based on which context the text field will be placed in and what works best with the applications design you are working with in general. 

For instance, the type label inside works well for more narrow spaces and label outside is a good option for forms with a lot of text fields present, making it easier for the users to decode the information

No label should be used very sparingly and only when needed. It is a good choice when adding text fields inside a data table, where a label will be present in the column head instead.

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text: There are two different text field sizes: default and medium where default is our primary text field size. Medium could be a good option to use for more narrow spaces. As for types, size could also be selected depending on what works best with the applications design you are working with.

Images.label: Default
Images.caption: Use as primary text field size

section.Title: States
section.Text: Text fields have different states to communicate the fields’ different status for our users.

Images.label: Focused
Images.caption: Highlighted by keyboard, voice or mouse

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text: A text field contains at least 3 elements; a text label and a container plus input text, when the user have input text.

Images.label: Label inside
Images.caption:
A. Container
B. Prefix icon/text (optional)
C. Label text
D. Input text
E. Suffix icon/text (optional)
F. Helper text (optional)

section.Text:
##### Container
Containers are the base of the text field, and it is a filled container with a bottom-border. The container has top rounded corners and square bottom corners. The bottom-border varies in height and colour depending on the state to emphasize this.

##### Label text
Label text is the text that communicates to the user what text information that should be submitted inside each text field.

##### Input text
Input text is the text that has been submitted by a user.

##### Prefix and Suffix icons
The prefix and suffix icons are optional. Prefix icons could be used to communicate to the user the valid input method and suffix icons are mainly used as actions, such as clear text or reveal a date picker. They could also be used to indicate another text format within the text field, such as password input or to highlight invalid text input.

##### Prefix and Suffix text
Prefix and suffix text are optional. They could be used to communicate a specific measurement unit, currency and such.

##### Helper text
Helper text assists the user with additional information text on how it will be used, display the maximum amount of characters limit or to describe an invald text input.

Images.label: Character counter
Images.caption: Used if there is a character limit

section.Text:
##### Placeholder text
Another way to assist users is to use a placeholder text, which hints of what type of information that should be entered. The placeholder text disappears when the user starts typing inside the text field.

##### Password text field
For a password input, we use a suffix icon to clarify that the user can show/hide the text input by pressing the icon. When hovering the icon, a tooltip explains the action.

##### Mandatory text field
When text fields are mandatory, there is two different ways to describe for the user what text field that is required or optional.

If a single text field or a couple of text fields in a form are required, indicate this by adding a asterisk * at the end of the Label text. To further highlight it, you can add a helper-text describing the asterisk.

If the majority of the text fields in a form are required, instead indicate the optional ones by adding the text (Optional) att the end of the Label text.

section.Title: Input types
section.Text:
There are two input types for how our text fields can display user input; single line or text areas.

Single line is used when the user should enter a single line text. Text areas should be used for input text with more than one sentence which requires multiple lines.

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for text fields.

##### Short label text
The label text should be short and direct and not be complex nor placed on multiple lines.

dosAndDonts.description: Short and direct label text
Long and complicated label text

section.Text:
##### Use one text field style
The text field style should be the same within one section or form.

dosAndDonts.description: Same text field style
Mix text field styles

section.Title: Colour
section.Text: Text fields come in different colours. Depending on what theme or background the text field exists on, the colour of the text field varies. More information about theming will be added during Q2 2021.

LeadText.textfield: Toggle helps the user to switch between the states on and off.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: Toggles are an efficient component when a user quickly should change between two states. They are primarly used within touch devices, but could also be used on non-touch devices as well. The most common usage scenario is to change the state on or off.

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text: There are two sizes for toggle; default and small, where default is our primary toggle size. The small can be used in narrowed spaces such as inside a data table.

section.Title: States
section.Text: A toggle can either be on or off. They also have different states to communicate the toggles different status for our users. These states are disabled, enabled, hover, focused and pressed.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
A toggle contains two mandatory elements, the switch and slider. It could also contain a two optional elements, a headline and label text. The lable text enhances the toggles mode on / off and the headline could be used to clarify what the toggle is switching on / off.

The switch is placed above the slider and the text to the right side of the toggle.

Image.caption:
A. Headline (optional) 
B. Slider
C. Switch
D. Label text (optional)

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for radio buttons.

##### Switch position
The switch position should always be placed to the right when the selected state is on (green). When it’s off, it should be positioned to the left (grey).

dosAndDonts.description: Place the switch to the right when selected state is on
Place the switch to the left when selected state is on

LeadText.textfield: A link is a reference and gateway to information located on the same page, to another page, or to an external location.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: Links should be used as navigation for users to find information, go to another section on the page, go to other pages and e-mail and phone numbers. When the link is placed within a sentence, it should visually be highlighted so that it is distinguised from the rest of the text. This is done by using another colour and/or using an underline.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
Links have two different types; internal and external link. Visually there is no difference, but an icon could be paired to clarify the action of the link.

**Internal links**
Target destination is to sections or pages on the same website/application.

**External links**
Target destination is to pages outside the website/application where the link exists.

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text: The link should have the same font-size as the text that it is positioned with. With that said, the link vary in size depending on its context.

section.Title: States
section.Text: Links have different states to communicate the different status for our users. These states are active, hover, focus, visited and disabled.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
The link contains one mandatory element; label text. The label text describes what the link is linked to.

It could also contain two optional element; underline and icon. 

Use the underline to emphasize that the link is an interactive element. The underline should be used when the link is within a sentence. In some components or patterns, the underline might not be needed due to the layout of the component or pattern. But when the link is placed in free text, we highly recommend to use the underline.

The icon could be used to clarify the action of the link, for instance use an external-arrow icon for an external link, or a download-arrow icon for a download file link. The icon should be placed to the right side of the label text.

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for links.

**Align text styles**

The link should have the same font-size as the text that it is positioned with.

dosAndDonts.description: Use the same font-size
Mix font-sizes

section.Text:
**Link vs button**

Links are not suitable inside a Login patterns as a CTA. For scenarios like this, button is the component to use.

dosAndDonts.description: Use a button as a CTA inside a Login pattern
Use link as a CTA inside a Login pattern

section.Text:
**Use sparingly**

When links are placed within sentences/paragraphs, make sure not to overuse too many links. This will clutter the entire experience and make it harder for the user to distingish what to do.

dosAndDonts.description: Use links sparingly within sentences, paragraphs and components
Overuse links within sentences, paragraphs and components

section.Title: Colour
section.Text:
Links have different states to communicate the different status for our users. These states are active, hover, focus, visited and disabled. Our default colour for a link is $blue-600. This is mainly used when it is placed within sentences and paragraphs on light backgrounds ($white, $grey-50 and $grey-100).

In some components or patterns, the colour needs to change depending on the background and context.

Below is an example of the default colour specifications.

State Property Colour
Active Text $blue-600
Hover Text $blue-500
Focus Outline $blue-500
Visited Text $grey-900
Disabled Text $gray-200

section.Title: Typography
section.Text: The link should start with the first letter set in upper case, and the remaining letters in lower case. It should also have the same font-size as the text that it is positioned with. With that said, the link vary in size depending on its context.

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text: Link will be styled automatically on all "a" elements when Scania theme component is added in an application. There is also a custom class available called "sdds-link".

LeadText.textfield: All of our user interfaces consist of components. These are our interactive building blocks, which we use to create new interfaces and applications sure to unpack complex technology, making information and functions immediately apparent for our users.

texts.textfield:
We have utilised a collection of reusable components which are aligned with our brand identity and expression. These components can be assembled together to build consistent and harmonised Scania applications. 

If you have a suggestion for a new component, [please let us know](contribution).

**The list of components will be updated regularly, with all of them being available during Q2.**

LeadText.textfield: Below you can check the progress of the work around components and see what you can expect in the near future. The list will be updated every two weeks. Feel free to contact us if you want one or more of the components be prioritized.
A card is a container used to display content and actions on  a single topic.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
Mainly a card serves as an entry point to more detailed information located on another internal or external page. The summary text should be clear, concise and easy to understand, to make it easy for the user to scan and find relevant information. Cards could also contain content such as images, buttons, icons and text links.

Cards are a good choice to use when presenting related content available on another section, page or articles.

It’s important that the cards have a container shadow present to add contrast between its background and the surface it appears on.

section.Title: Placement
section.Text:
Cards do not have a specific place on a page. Their placement can be decided based on the need and context, i.e. cards can be placed at the centre of the screen or left/right aligned side by side with text or other media content. 

Orientation of cards can be vertical or horizontal depending on the requirement of the content for the specific card.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
A card only has one mandatory element, its container. The rest of the elements are optional. The container is the element that group all the card elements together. Thumbnails are used for images such as icons, avatars or logotypes.

The card has three different text elements. The header text is the title of the card, which should capsulate the card content. If needed, you can use the subheader text to support the header text. The third text element, supporting text, is used for more descriptive summary text.

Images can be used in the cards as well as actions such as icons, buttons or text links. Note, the entire card could be clickable so buttons or text links should only be used if you have several links present on the card or if you want to highlight the CTA.

Images.caption:
A. Container
B. Thumbnail (optional)
C. Header text (optional)
D. Sub-header text (optional)
E. Image (optional)
F. Supporting text (optional)
G. Button or link (optional)
H. Icons (optional)

section.Text:
**Dividers**

It is also possible to use dividers in our cards to group or separate specific content and to distinguish revealed content on an expanded card. Note, these should be used sparingly.

section.Title: Layout
section.Text:
The layout of the card is modular and will vary depending on which elements that are used and what type of content hierachy that is needed for the specific card.

For example, in a card with image, the image could either be placed above or below the header text. It could also either be stacked horizontally or vertically with the rest of the card’s elements.

We do recommend to always place the action elements, button or links, in the bottom of card to maintain consistency for navigation. And to group the header and subheader text when used.

section.Title: Behaviour
section.Text:
**Expandable**

Cards can be expanded in order to reveal additional information inside the card.

**Re-organize**

When multiple cards are displayed on a section or a page, dragging and reorganizing cards may be proposed.

**Scrolling**

When and only when there is a need to display a long supporting text on reveal, scrolling may be proposed.

section.Title: States
section.Text:
Normally the entire card container is linked, and when it is, it has different states to communicate the different status for our users. These states are default, hover, focused, pressed and dragged.

When the cards container is not linked, it has fewer states. These states are enabled and focused.

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for cards.

**Working with links**

Cards are a good choice to use when presenting related content available on another section, page or articles. Make sure just to use a couple of  links on each card to make it useful for our users.

dosAndDonts.description: Use links sparingly
Use many links in the supporting text

section.Text:
**Positioning action elements**

We do recommend to always place the action elements, button, links and icons in the bottom of card to be maintain consistency for navigation.

dosAndDonts.description: Place the action links in the bottom of the card
Place action links in any other position than the bottom of the card

section.Title: Box-shadow
section.Text:
The cards container always has the background $white. Depending on what theme or content background colour the card exists on, the box-shadow of the card varies. When placed on $white content background, the box-shadow is slightly stronger than on a $grey-50 background, since we need to add some more contrast between the cards container background with the content background.

Note, more additional information about theming will be released later this year.
##### $on-white

State Container Box-shadow
Default $white 0px 3px 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.15), 0px -1px 1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)
Hover $white 0px 3px 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.25), 0px -1px 1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)
Focused $white 0px 3px 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.35), 0px -1px 1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)
Pressed $white 0px 1px 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.25), 0px -1px 1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)
Dragged $white 0px 3px 6px 2px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2), 0px -1px 1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)
##### $on-grey

State Container Box-shadow

Hover $white 0px 3px 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2), 0px -1px 1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text:
Since the layout of the card is modular, there is no defined sizing specs for the card. Depending on the content and its needs, the card containers width and height therefore varies.

**Examples**

Below shows a variety of different cards to get an understanding for how they are structured, both in sizing and how to organize elements within the container.

##### Container width
As the rest of our components, the card width and height should be based on our [Unit System](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/foundations/unit-grid-system/code). A good way to achieve visual balance in your layout is to align the card container's width with your application's grid systems columns. The card width can take a maximum of 8 columns and, for most cases, will take the full width of the grid layout only on mobile screens.

section.Text: The card has rounded corners with a 4px / 1 rem corner radius.

section.Text:
Card is works like a container to present content with a specific action. The action can be the card it self or with inside the footer as a link. Card is a very flexible component.
Card is built on three container options: 
- Header
- Body
- Footer

Inside the header you can place headlines and avatar image. Inside the body you have the support text for the card. Inside the footer is the placement for the actions like links or button. 
Divider component can be used inside the card to create a divider line between, for example the header and body. It also has support for image placement in both the top and middle of the card.

LeadText.textfield: Breadcrumbs support the navigation within an application. They make the users aware of their current location and display options for further navigation back.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
Breadcrumbs are not to be seen as a replacement of the primary navigation. Instead, breadcrumbs are used to complement the primary navigation. They are placed in line with the proper hierarchy shown in the order of the links. The first link of the breadcrumbs is the link to the homepage and the last link, which is inactive, shows the current location of the user.

Breadcrumbs are an easy and quick way for the user to jump back in the hierarchy level. Mainly use it for large or complex websites/applications.

**Truncation option**

There might be a scenario where the current page name is very long and we do need to truncate it. Use a [tootip](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components/Tooltip) to show the entire page name, which will appear when the user hovers the truncated page name.

section.Title: Placement
section.Text: Breadcrumbs are positioned at the top left of the page, above the page title and below the primary navigation. They are not shown on the first level (eg home page).

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text: The breadcrumbs contain two mandatory elements; link text and separator. The link text is the name of the section or a page. All link texts are clickable links, except the last one. The separator visually distinguish the different pages.

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for breadcrumbs.

**Separator character**

Make sure to use the character ‘›’ (single right-pointing angle quotation mark) between the breadcrumbs to indicate the hiearchy of the navigational structure.

dosAndDonts.description: Use › to indicate the hierarchy of the navigational structure
Use characters that do not underline the hierarchy of the navigational structure

section.Text:
**Truncation with care**

Make sure to only truncate one page name in the breadcrumbs. If multiple page names will be truncated, the purpose of the breadcrumbs will get lost since the user will not get a clear overview of the navigational hiearchy.

dosAndDonts.description: Truncate one page name
Truncate multiple page names

section.Title: Colour
section.Text: The breadcrumbs links have different states to communicate the different status for our users. These states are active, hover, focus and disabled. The separator is not a clickable element and is always present in one colour.

State Link text Separator
Active $grey-800 $grey-300
Hover $grey-500 $grey-300
Focus Outline $grey-300
Disabled $grey-200 $gray-300

section.Title: Typography
section.Text: The link text and separator are available in one and the same text style.

Text Text style
Link text $detail-05
Separator $detail-05

LeadText.textfield: Modals disrupts the workflow to focus users’ attention to a specific task or message to complete before resuming their workflow.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: Modals are tightly integrated into user’s workflow to present information for users to take the next steps in their workflow. They can also be used to provide feedback from the system to the user, and to prompt users to take action or to notify users about information that is important for them to accomplish their task.

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text:
The modals overlay will completely cover the entire page in the application, while the modal container needs to be adjusted to the content it will contain. 

The modal comes in four sizes; large, medium, small and xsmall, where medium is our primary modal size. XSmall and Small should be used for shorter messages, and medium and large should be used for larger amount of content in combination with complex components. Select the modal size that works best for the content that you want to add to the modal.

##### XSmall
Used to display short messages.

##### Small
Used for messages with multiple lines of text, together with a couple of components.

##### Medium
Used for moderate amount of content like text in combination with components like multiple forms or wizards.

##### Large
Used for larger amounts of content like text in combination with components like multiple forms or wizards.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
The modal always consists of the following elements; card, close icon, header text and overlay.

The overlay will completely cover the entire page in the application, and the card will be positioned above the overlay. The close icon is always positioned in the top-right corner of the modal, which will close the modal when being pressed.

An overlay could also contain a lot of other elements, such as body text, components like text fields, check boxes along with actions such as buttons. 

Below is an example of a modal, to show a possible composition of a modal pattern. You can read more about the different modal patterns that exist in our [modal pattern section.](link)

Image.caption:
A. Header text
B. Card
C. Overlay
D. Close icon
E. Body text
F. Text field
G. Dropdown
H. Buttons

section.Title: Do's and Don'ts
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for modals.

##### Use modals with caution
The purpose of modals is to disrupt the workflow and present a message that blocks the user from continuing until the modal is dismissed. For this reason, modals can be frustrating when used for communicating non-critical messages or actions that is not related to the task.

For less critical and task unrelated messages, it’s better to use non disruptive components like [banners](components/banners) or [components](toasts).

dosAndDonts.description: Use modals to direct users focus to important actions related to their task or critical information
Be that guy

section.Title: Colour
section.Text: All components used in the modal, should follow the colours specified for each component.

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text:
##### Sizes
The modal comes in four sizes; large, medium, small and xsmall. The widths are based on our grid systems columns, and will vary in width depending on the breakpoint size. The height of the modal depends on the content inside the card, and will therefore vary.

##### Mobile size
On mobile devices, all of our modals are aligned to the grid system columns and covering 4 of 4 columns. The modal height can either adapts to its content, or take the full viewport height and width.

##### Spacing
Since the content of the card will vary, you need to define the spacing for the elements that you are using. We do have some specific spacing defined, for instance we are always using the same side-margins (16px / 4rem) as well as specific margin between the header text and the content below (16px / 4rem). The spacing between the content, if a card does not have any actions, is also fixed (40px / 10rem).

When creating new modals, make sure to use our [Layout scale](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/foundations/spacing/information#layout-scale), which is using our Unit System, when adding space between the elements that are being used.

Below shows a variety of different modals to get an understanding for how they are structured and how to organize the elements within our cards.

The spacing between the close icon and other elements remains the same for all modal sizes. Nevertheless, some margins can vary between different elements on smaller modal sizes such as the right margins. For instance, in our smallest modals XSmall and Small, the right side of the text container aligns to the close icon instead of keeping 48px spacing in between (see example below).

section.Title: Typography
section.Text: The header text should start with the first letter set in upper case, and the remaining letters in lower case. Always keep the header text short and concise.

section.Title: Corner radius
section.Text: The card has rounded corners with a 4px / 1 rem corner radius.

LeadText.textfield: Forms are a collection of input components put together to allow users to provide data or configure options.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: There is usually a high degree of freedom when designing forms, considering that there are infinite variations that can be generated when combining components in different ways. That is exactly why it is particularly important to have some guidelines that will be followed, in order to achieve a consistent result which is effective and efficient for users to interact with.

section.Title: Types
section.Text: The most common forms used within Scania are standard forms, full-width forms, multi-step forms and modal forms, all of which can be seen below.

section.Title: Standard form
section.Text:
A standard form is one of our most commonly used forms. It is preferable for less extensive forms and works well on pages consisting of other types of content. 

Our standard form extends over a maximum of 8 columns and can be adjusted to the left or to the centre.

###### Left aligned
###### Centre aligned

section.Title: Full-width form
section.Text: As the name suggests, a full-width form extends the full width of a page, and should be used when the form is the most important element on a particular page. It works best when spacing is valued high. However, if the form ends up being very long, other variations of forms are suggested i.e. multi-step form.

section.Title: Multi-step form
section.Text:
If your form grows in size to include a lot of information, it is recommended that you use a multi-step form, as it can be overwhelming to display all input elements on a single page. 

A multi-step form instead spreads the content across multiple pages and includes a progress bar to track the users' progress while making it possible to travel back and forth within the form.

There are two variants of multi-step forms; horizontal and vertical.

##### a. Multi-step horizontal
This form should be used when the steps are limited, i.e. about 4 to 5.

##### b. Multi-step vertical
This form should be used for more complex forms, when the different steps are more than 6.

section.Title: Modal form
section.Text: Sometimes a form is not part of a page but part of a larger context. In these cases, it is preferable to display the form in the form of a modal. This solution is also suitable when the focus should be entirely on the form. However, it is important to point out that in such a solution, the form should not be too long.

section.Title: Mobile
section.Text: On mobile devices, we stack all input elements on top of each other. Input elements take up 100% of the width while the width of the button is dictated by its content.

section.Title: Anatomy of a form
section.Text:
Forms are made up of several components, some of which are [Text fields](components/textfields), [Dropdowns](components/dropdowns), [Radio buttons](components/radio-buttons) and [Buttons](components/buttons). It’s up to each designer to choose the most suitable components for his or hers respective need. 

Below you can see an example of a standard form.

Image.caption:
A. Form title
B. Brief description (Optional)
C. Label
D. Text inputs
E. Data inputs
F. Button

section.Text:
##### Components
Here is a list of components that are associated with forms.

section.Title: Building a form
section.Text:
When creating a form, it is important to consider spacing and key adjustments. This varies depending on the context and placement of the form. As an example, the spacing in a modal form or mobile form will not be the same as for a full-width form. However, there are certain key principles regarding spacing that can be applied to create a cohesive experience throughout.

Here is a good approach to follow:

- Start by selecting an initial value based on our Unit System
- This value represents your spacing between the form title and your first input
- For spacing between input elements (Text fields, Dropdowns, Radio buttons etc), take the initial value and subtract with 8px if your initial value is 24px and above, or 4px if the initial value is 20px and below.
- For spacing between the last input and the button or button group, take the initial value and add 8px if your initial value is 24px and above or 4px if the initial value is 20px and below.

The table below serves as a cheat sheet for some of the more common values. Recommended initial value for standard forms is 32px.
##### Common spacings

section.tableHtml:
Initial value Spacing between inputs Spacing between last input and call to action
16 px / 4 rem 12 px / 3 rem 20 px / 5 rem
20 px / 5 rem 16 px / 4 rem 24 px / 6 rem
24 px / 6 rem 16 px / 4 rem 32 px / 8 rem
32 px / 8 rem 24 px / 6 rem 40 px / 10 rem
40 px / 10 rem 32 px / 8 rem 48 px / 12 rem

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice examples for forms.

##### Alignment
Make sure to align all the elements within the form

dosAndDonts.description: Align all elements
Align the text

section.Text:
##### Layout
When designing your form, consider your choice of layout. The desire is to create a smooth flow through the form that makes it easy for the user to scan. A misaligned form is hard to follow and creates poor scannability, the same applies to forms designed on a single line.

dosAndDonts.description: Make sure that the form lines up and flows vertically.
Misalign the input elements
Design single-line forms

section.Text:
##### Consider the length of your form
Try to avoid long scrollable forms. If your form grows too large, it may be a good idea to consider another type of form, e.g.  a multi-step form.

dosAndDonts.description: Use a multi-step form when there are many inputs
Long scrollable forms

section.Text:
##### Use one text field style
The text field style should be the same within one section or form.

dosAndDonts.description: Same text field style
Mix text field styles

LeadText.textfield: Scania’s pictogram family helps us to organise and categorise information. Speaking the universal language of symbols, our pictograms facilitate the encounter with the Scania brand. They create a unified and uncluttered experience in every channel.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
The design of the pictograms is inspired by the shapes in our symbol, the Scania Sans typography and our product DNA.

Sometimes the information we need to bring across is detailed, and even complex. Our illustrative pictograms help visualising information in a simplified way, always combined with supportive text. Correctly used, pictograms improve the structure and clarity of any message. Pictograms can be use both on digital and physical environments.

Pictograms shouldn’t be confused with icons, smaller non-decorative visual element which purpose is to highlight functions or actions on digital interfaces.

section.Title: Size
section.Text:
Our pictograms are designed in a 40x40 px grid as a master grid size. They can then be proportionally scaled up to the sizes needed.

Please note that if you want to use pictograms for sizes smaller than 40x40 px, icons might be preferable. Find more information about icons usage on the related [Icon Usage](foundations/icons) page.

Images.caption: Pictograms are meant to be used in big sizes starting from 40px and above, following our Unit system.
Draw the pictogram on a master grid of 40x40px.

Once the two styles are created, outline the stroke and scale the master grid to the sizes wanted. We recommand to use Bold style up to 88x88px pictogram size. From this size and above, we advise to use the Regular style.

texts.textfield: In order to optimize pictograms throughout their different application, always create them in two different styles: bold and regular. This way they will be optimized for a use on both normal and large sizes.

section.Text:
Icon style Stroke width Master size Output size
Bold 2px 40x40px < 88px
Regular 1,5px 40x40px > 88px

section.Title: Guidelines
section.Text:
The grid offers guidelines for some basic shapes and proportions as a starting point when designing new pictograms. This includes keyshapes and angles which derives from the Scania logo anatomy. Adhering to these guides will help create consistency across our pictograms library. 

Please note that these guides should be seen as starting points. Deviations from these guides are accepted if it makes a specific pictogram more clear in its design. It is allowed to use the margins with small objects to ensure that the pictograms feel centered.

##### Clearspace
Our pictogram grid keep a clearspace of 4px around.

##### Curvature
The curvature consists of a compilation of circles which follows our unit system. The curvature is a good guide to ensure a consistent visual expression throughout all our pictograms.

Images.caption: 1. As full, half or quarter circles.
2. Depending on the motif they are a part of.

texts.textfield: The curvature can be applied in two different ways:

section.Title: Level of detail
section.Text:
When creating pictograms, the key is to find the right level of detail. The pictograms should translate Scania look and feel, but they also should avoid too much complexity in order to communicate their meaning efficiently.

In the same way, pictograms shouldn’t be too simplified risking losing the Scania DNA. In those cases, try to add some details. The curvature is also here to help to inject these characteristics, but its use must not be forced into the design.

section.Title: Meaning
section.Text: Avoid combining more than one pictogram into new combinations of pictograms. Choose the one that best communicates what you want. If the pictogram does not in its own right communicate what it represents, add supporting text in the context where it is used. The same pictogram can be used to communicate more than one thing. Before designing new one, start by looking in our pictogram library for suitable pictograms.

Images.caption: Example: The same pictogram can represent different subject by giving it context and supporting text.

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for pictograms.

texts.textfield:
##### Illustrative purpose
Pictograms must only be used for illustrative purpose and in combination with supporting text. For smaller sizes and non-decorative purpose, use icons.

dosAndDonts.description: Use pictogram as a visual supporting element combined with a text.
Use pictograms as a substitute for UI icons, that is not their purpose.

section.Title: Resources
section.Text: You can download all our pictograms below. If you are looking for a specific one, please browse our Pictogram Library.

LeadText.textfield: All our pictograms are available in the list below, where you can download or copy the HTML snippet for specific pictograms. Simply browse the list or search to find what you are looking for.

LeadText.textfield: If you need a pictogram, please check thoroughly in our pictogram library if you could use any of the already existing ones. Should the needed pictogram not exist, you may create a new pictogram following the guidelines below.

section.Title: Re-use elements
section.Text:
Please note that already existing pictogram elements should be re-used as far as possible. As an example for “electricity/power”, the same element (flash) is used in both the battery and the Scania Gensets pictogram. 

Another one is the element “tyre”, which is used both in the pictogram for conditions roads and tyre service.

section.Title: Construct a pictogram
section.Text:
Below you can find detailed information about how to build a new custom pictogram, using Adobe Illustrator. You can also download our Pictogram template file to use as a base when designing.

##### Guiding steps

Images.label: Step 1 — Grid settings
Images.caption: A squared shape pixel grid (40x40px) is used as a base to construct pictograms. To match the optical volume, sub-containers help to suit various pictograms format.

Images.label: Step 2 — Line width
Images.caption: The line width for a 48x48px pictogram is 2px and will adjust proportionally when scaling up in order to achieve a consistent optical appearance between pictograms.

Images.label: Step 3 — Use rounded corners
Images.caption: For outside edges and curved angles use the curvature. All pictograms corners should be rounded.
The minimum clear space around the pictogram is 4px.

section.Title: Contribution process
section.Text:
##### Approval
Before finalising the pictogram, the pictogram design including name and description/restrictions, must be approved by any of the central departments Marketing Communications or Brand Management or the Scania Identity Helpdesk at identity@scania.com.

##### File versions and formats
Before exporting the pictogram, make sure to convert all strokes to outlines and unite the pictogram to one single path. Always keep a version of the original construction path in your file in order for the community to be able to work with it more easily.

All new pictogram must always be saved in two versions (positive and negative) and two file formats (.ai and .svg) - in total 4 files for each pictogram:

##### Positive version: Scania Blue
- SVG files: RGB 4_30_66
- AI files: CMYK 100_90_13_62

##### Negative version: Scania White
- SVG files: RGB 255_255_255
- AI files: CMYK 0_0_0_0

##### Formats
- AI file format for use in print
- SVG file format for digital use

##### Naming
The pictogram file name should be concise and descriptive. More specifically, it should follow the following format 

*descriptive_name.format* or *descriptive_name-neg.format* (in case of negative pictogram)

Keep in mind:

- Do not use uppercase letters at all
- Dashes should only be used between the icon name and the suffix for the negative version, in case this exists.
- Spaces should not be used at all.

As an example, the file names for e.g. “Truck service” would then be:
</br>*truck_service.ai /.svg*
</br>*truck_service-neg.ai /.svg*

##### Delivery
All pictogram files are sent as a zip file containing all 4 file variations to [identity@scania.com](identity@scania.com) in order to be published in the Scania Digital Design System. It is strongly suggested that you also include a short description of the pictogram, as well as 
any restrictions for use of the it (if any exist).

Delivering the pictogram files also means that it is approved to be published as well as archived in the Scania Digital Design System. The pictogram may also be used by other users, for its intended purpose and as long as the restrictions (if any) are respected. 

##### Support
Should you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact Scania Identity Helpdesk at [identity@scania.com](identity@scania.com).

LeadText.textfield: Scania Digital Design System's icons package will help you implement the official pictograms and icons in your application in an easy way.

section.Title: Installation
section.Text: There are 2 options to use icons package. You can use it as a module or as a webfont. ##### Use as a module with sdds-icon component This is a good option if your application supports script bundling, and for example you need all resources to be offline or hosted in your own server. To install icons package as a module, install using [npm](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@scania/icons). ``` npm i @scania/icons --save ``` Then you can use it together with 'sdds-icon' component. It will only load icon that are used your application. If you are using a bundler such as webpack, it will only bundle the icons that are used in your application. ``` ``` ##### Webfont All icons are available as font icons. Import the font CSS from Scania CDN in your CSS or HTML. The CSS for icon webfont is available here: https://cdn.digitaldesign.scania.com/icons/dist/1.0.0/fonts/css/sdds-icons.css ``` // in CSS @import url('https://cdn.digitaldesign.scania.com/icons/dist/1.0.0/fonts/css/sdds-icons.css'); //OR you can add it in the HTML inside ``` Then, you can use it as a class in your element. Do not forget to add 'sdds-icon' class before the icon name. ``` ```

LeadText.textfield: Data tables consist of columns and rows, and are useful to organise large amounts of data and clearly display them.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: Data tables are perfect to use when data needs to be organised and displayed in a way that help users to easily scan and look for patterns, as well as to develop insights from the actual data. Depending on the type of data table, the user can sort data in both ascending and descending order, expand rows to reveal more information and perform actions.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
Our data tables comes in different variations and features, to support several user needs when displaying data. We have highlighted on this page four commonly used data table patterns in addition to its initial structure: sorting, multiple row selection, single row selection, and expandable row. 

Other data table patterns containing interactive elements such as filtering, multiple pages, inline elements, buttons and status chips also exist and are gathered on the data tables patterns page (link to be added soon).

##### Default

The core structure of a data table consists of multiple rows and columns displaying textual data. It contains the column headers and their related data cells.

##### Sorting

The default aspect of a data table can be enriched with a sorting functionnality, which enables users to sort each column content in ascending and descending order. When hovering a column header, the user is able to toggle between both classification by clicking on the arrow icon appearing on the selected column header. The direction of the arrow icon indicates if the sorting is in an ascending or descending order. The header of the sorted column will remain highlighted.

##### Multiple row selection

Multiple row selection is useful when the user needs to select multiple rows simultaneously  to perform certain actions such as edit, delete or copy. The selected rows are highlighted.

##### Single row selection

Single row selection should be used when the user can only perform action on one single row at a time. The selected row is highlighted.

##### Expandable row

If there is a large amount of data that needs to be placed in a row, we recommend to not showcase all information at once. Instead, use an expandable row where the secondary detailed information can be placed inside the expanded area, which will be revealed when the user clicks on the row. The expandable row must only contain textual content and should follow the column's layout.

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text: There are two different row sizes: default and compact. Default is the primary size, and compact can be used in narrowed spaces, where space is limited.

section.Title: States
section.Text:
The data tables columns are available in default, hover, and selected states. The hover state could be used even if the data table is not interactive. When one cell is hovered, the full row is hovered as well. The different states make it easier for users to scan and decode the data within the data table.

Depending on the type of data table you are using, it will contain various elements which will have different states communicating different status to users. A data table could contain other components such as radio buttons, checkboxes, and buttons. These have the same states as defined in their respective component page.

The options to filter, add multiple pages, inline elements, buttons, and status chips also exist and their various states can be found in the data tables pattern page (will be added soon).

Image.caption: When users hover a column header, all the cells from the corresponding column are highlighted too.
When users hover a content cell, all the cells from the same row are highlighted too.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
A data table primarily consists of columns and rows, where the columns span vertically and the rows span horizontally. 

The data table header is an optional element that could be used when you have a lot of different data tables in your applications, in order for the user to find the right one more easily. The header row contains the column headers, and could also contain a select item, such as checkboxes, and sorting functionalities. 

The rows contain the data, and these can be expandable to reveal more information if needed, as well as being selectable.
The column divider is also an optional element, which could be used to further highlight the different columns when there are many and small columns present in the data table.

Image.caption:
A. Data table header (Optional)
B. Header row
C. Row
D. Column divider (Optional)

section.Title: Scrolling
section.Text: Scrolling can be enabled vertically and horizontally to help users scanning the information more easily and avoid displaying a big amount of data. These scroll patterns can be used separately and be combined.

##### Vertical scrolling

Vertical scrolling is useful when a table consists of more rows than you would like to show at once. By setting a maximum amount of rows limit, a scrollbar will appear to help users being aware of where they are in the table list. Columns headers will remain sticky to help users keep track of the different column categories.

Image.caption: Vertical scrolling is recommended when a data table contains more than eight rows.

section.Text:
##### Horizontal scrolling

Horizontal scrolling enables users to browse larger amounts of columns without making the entire page scroll. By setting a maximum amount of columns limit, a horizontal scrollbar will appear. It is possible to lock columns to ease tracking while scrolling horizontally and to maintain context.

Image.caption: Horizontal scrolling is recommended when a data table contains more than five columns.

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for data tables.

##### Arrange columns in order of importance
Data tables can easily get out of hand with an extensive amount of columns, making horizontal scrolling necessary. In order to help users find the important information first, you should prioritize the columns, and sort them from the most important to the less important, from left to right.

dosAndDonts.description: Prioritize the columns and sort the most important information starting from left to right
Place columns in random order

section.Text:
##### Consistent row size
When creating a data table, make sure to only use one row size inside it. By mixing the sizes, you will establish a bad user experience with poor readability.

dosAndDonts.description: Use the same row size
Mix the row sizes

section.Text:
##### Top-left alignment
Make sure that the content of each cell expands from its top-left corner with 16px padding.

dosAndDonts.description: Always top-left align content in each cell with 16px padding around
Randomly align the content of the cells

section.Text:
##### Horizontal alignment
Make sure that the content of each cells are left-aligned.

dosAndDonts.description: Always horizontally left-align the content in each cell
Center-align or right-align the content of a cell

section.Title: Colour
section.Text: Colours are essential visual cues to help users easily and quickly scan the information contained in the data table. The data tables cells have different states to communicate the different status for our users. Depending on which theme or background colour the data table lives on, the colour of these states varies.

##### Data table header 

The data table header only have a default state, and the same style applies both $on-grey and $on-white light theme variants.

##### Column header

The column header has a default, hover, and selected state. The same style applies both for $on-white and $on-grey.

##### Data table cell Data table cells have three different states: default, hover, and selected. Their style differs depending on which theme or color background they exist on. The hover state applies even if the cell is not interactive. ###### $on-grey
State Container Text Bottom-border
Default white $grey-900 $blue-100
Hover $blue-50 $grey-900 $blue-100
Selected $blue-100 $grey-900 $blue-200

###### $on-white
State Container Text Bottom-border
Default $grey-50 $grey-900 $grey-100
Hover $blue-100 $grey-900 $blue-200
Selected $blue-200 $grey-900 $blue-300

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text:
The size of the data table depends on the data it contains, and will therefore vary. Its height is defined by the number of rows it includes. Its width varies since each cell width expands accordingly with its content while keeping consistent padding values. We advise setting a maximum limit of eight rows and five columns, and use scrolling over these values to prevent information overload.

##### Cells
Each table cell has a minimum width of 192 pixels. If the cell content exceeds the minimum width, the cell then grows accordingly. Table cells have a fixed padding of 16px.

As described under the usage tab, our data tables comes in two sizes: default and compact. The height of their rows are respectively 48px and 32px. In some specific use cases where a cell contains a long text that can’t fit on one line, the cell height adapts accordingly to the content, maintaining a 16px padding for default size and 8px padding for compact size. You can see this last use case in context in the rows section below.

##### Rows Rows have a flexible width which adapts to the numbers of cells it contains. Data tables should contain a minimum of two rows. Two different row sizes exist: default and compact. Compact can be used in narrowed spaces, where space is limited.
Size Width px/rem Height px/rem
Default Width varies 48 / 12
Compact Width varies 32 / 8
In some specific use case, a row could contain cells with text displayed on multiple lines. In this case, the full row height adapts to the larger height value in the row.

##### Header The data table header is positioned behind the column header and is available in two sizes: default and compact.
Size Width px/rem Height px/rem
Default Width varies 112 / 28
Compact Width varies 88 / 12

##### Columns

Columns have a flexible width which adapts to the content and respect padding of 16 px on both sides. Data tables should contain a minimum of two columns.

##### Data table
The size of the data table doesn’t expand with the viewport size. Its width and height remain the same regardless of the viewport expansion.
Nonetheless, on smaller breakpoints and devices, $medium (tablet) and $small (mobile), the width of the data table decreases accordingly with the browser window, and horizontal scrolling applies.
##### Sorting

When hovering the column header, all the cells from the corresponding column are hovered too. When the sorting action is activated, the column header state is selected and the column cells remain in their default state.

Image.caption: Hover on the third column header.
Sorted order activated on the third column.

section.Text: ##### Multiple row selection
##### Single row selection
##### Expandable row

section.Title: Typography
section.Text:
The data table header and column header starts with the first letter set in upper case, and the remaining letters in lower case.
Text Text style
Data table header $headline-07
Column header $headline-07
Information text $detail-02

section.Title: Corner radius
section.Text:
The data table headers have top rounded corners with a 4px / 1rem corner radius and the bottom corners are squared. The column headers corner radius varies depending on the position of the column header. The column header that is positioned first in the row has a top left rounded corner with a 4px / 1rem corner radiuss, and the column header that is positioned last in the row has a top right rounded corner with a 4px / 1rem corner radius. They always have squared bottom corners. All the corners on our cells are also always squared.
Corner radius Corners
4 px / 1 rem Top left & right corners
0 px / 0 rem Bottom left & right corners

Image.label: Example
Image.caption: Column header positioned first in the row

LeadText.textfield: This section is currently under construction and is planned to be done in Q2 2021.
Toast notifications are short messages used to give users low- or mid- priority feedback on the status of an action.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
To ensure a good usage of this component and get more context about which notification variant to use, please refer to the notifications pattern page (page will be available soon).

Toast notifications provide users with feedback on an action they have performed, e.g. “Your file has been saved successfully”. They should be clear and concise, and can optionally contain a single action. Depending on the type of notification, toasts can either be persistent (stay on the page until they are dismissed by the user) or transient (they automatically disappear after a set amount of time).

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text: Toasts have a fixed width of 352 px and their height varies depending on their content. Nevertheless, their height shouldn’t exceed 116 px.

It is recommended to keep the subheader as short and straightforward as possible. In the case where extra content is needed for more clarity, the text will be truncated to fit the width of the text container, and users will be able to access the full content by clicking on a link.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
The toast should convey a clear and concise message. Thus its textual content must be as short and straightforward as possible, avoiding repetition and unnecessary details. These guidelines enable users to grasp the information in a short amount of time and quickly understand the following steps they need to take.  

The coloured left border indicates the type of message displayed in the toast.

The prefix icon supports the left border highlighting the nature of the message. It is filled with the corresponding colour.

The header should convey the main message in very few words to be clear and effective. 

The subheader helps users to understand what action is expecting from them. It supports the header text if extra information is needed for more clarity. Avoid paraphrasing the header and do not use the subheader when the header is sufficient. 

The link label must be short (one or two words) and describe explicitly the action taken by clicking on it.

Image.label: Toast
Image.caption:
A. Left border
B. Container
C. Prefix icon
D. Header text
E. Close icon
F. Subheader text (optional)
G. Link (optional)

section.Title: Placement
section.Text: The toast notification is placed on the bottom right corner of the viewport on top of the page content. It has a fixed position on scroll.

section.Title: Message type
section.Text:
Toast notifications can display four different types of messages: success, information, warning and error messages. The distinction between each of them is visually translated through the use of four different colours, as well as a prefix icon.

##### Success toast
When an action has been executed successfully</br>
e.g. Your files have been saved successfully

##### Information toast
When an action has been executed successfully, but further information needs to be provided</br>
e.g. 37 duplicate files might exist

##### Warning toast
When an action cannot be performed due to external factors.</br>
e.g. Specified people don’t have permission

##### Error toast
When an action cannot be performed due to system issues</br>
e.g. There is another file with the same name

Note: icon success + information + warning + error are not yet designed.

Image.label: Message type
Image.caption:
A. Success
B. Information
C. Warning
D. Error

section.Title: Behaviour
section.Text:
Toast notifications behave in two different ways: 
1. Transient - they disappear after a set amount of time, which is suggested to not be less than 5 seconds.
2. Persistent - they are visible until the user dismisses them

##### Dismissal
Every type of toast contains a close icon on its top-right corner which enables the user to dismiss it. In the case where toast notifications dismiss automatically, there is an option for users to access them after they disappeared, depending on the application need. These toasts will be indicated with a badge. For more information, please refer to the badges page (will be added soon).

Images.caption: A cross icon on the top-right corner to dismiss the toast.
Transient toasts which have disappeared can be indicated by a badge.

section.Text: Success messages should always be transient, since they are purely informative and users do not need to take an extra action. On the other hand, error and warning messages should always be persistent, considering that grabbing user’s attention is important. Finally, informative messages can either be transient or persistent, based on each individual use case.

##### Appearing animations
The toast quickly appears from the bottom of the viewport and slows down to a stop. The toast appears with an opacity fade-in animation, coming from the bottom of the viewport while keeping a fixed X position.

Note: animation styles will be available soon

##### Disappearing animation
The toast leaves the viewport to the right. It speeds up as it exits while applying an opacity fade-out animation.

Note: animation styles will be available soon

##### Multiple toasts
When multiple toasts appear at the same time, they are stacked under each other with a spacing of 8px in between. A maximum of two toasts displayed simultaneously is preferred. For more information regarding multiple toasts behaviour, please refer to the notifications pattern page (will be available soon). To get more context regarding multiple toasts behaviour on small screens, please refer to the notifications pattern page.

##### On small screens
On smaller screens, the toasts don’t stack to prevent hiding the content as the space is limited. Only one toast can be shown at a time. The toasts that disappeared are indicated with a badge. For more information please refer to the badges page (will be available soon). To get more context regarding multiple toasts behaviour on small screens, please refer to the notifications pattern page (will be available soon).

section.Title: Do and Don’ts
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for toasts.

##### Toast on small screen
As space is limited on small screens, only one toast notification should be shown at a time. Do not stack multiple toast notifications under each other.

dosAndDonts.description: Place the toast on the bottom of the viewport following the layout grid
Stack toasts on small screen

section.Text:
##### Content
Keep the content clear and concise.

dosAndDonts.description: Ensure that the text displayed on the toast is clear and concise
Do not use long text

section.Text:
##### Usage
Do not use banners instead of toasts.

dosAndDonts.description: Use toasts for action-based messages
Do not use banners in place of toasts

section.Text:
##### Action
Only one action can be perform through the toasts.

dosAndDonts.description: Only allow users to perform one action
Allow multiple actions

section.Title: Box shadow
section.Text:
The toasts container always has the background $grey-900. Depending on what theme or content background colour the toasts exists on, the box-shadow of the card varies. When placed on $white content background, the box-shadow is slightly stronger than on a $grey-50 background, since we need to add some more contrast between the cards container background with the content background.

Note: more additional information about theming will be released later this year.

##### $on-white
State Container Box-shadow
Default $grey-900 0px 3px 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.15), 0px -1px 1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)

##### $on-grey
State Container Box-shadow
Default $grey-900 0px 3px 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1), 0px -1px 1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05)

section.Title: Colour
section.Text:
The colour plays an essential role in the toast component as it indicates the type of messages displayed. All the different types of toasts have the same background referring to the $grey-900.
Type Container Icon Text Link Left-border
Success $grey-900 $green-500 $grey-50 $blue-400 $green-500
Information $grey-900 $blue-500 $grey-50 $blue-400 $blue-500
Warning $grey-900 $orange-500 $grey-50 $blue-400 $orange-500
Error $grey-900 $red-500 $grey-50 $blue-400 $red-500

##### Success
Success messages are indicated with the use of $green-500, as well as a $green-500 filled success prefix icon.

##### Information
Informative messages are visually translated with the use of $blue-500, as well as a $blue-500 filled information prefix icon.

##### Warning
Warning messages are translated with the use of $orange-500, as well as an $orange-500 filled warning prefix icon.

##### Error
Error messages are translated with the use of $red-500, as well as a $red-500 filled error prefix icon. When designing the error icon, make sure that it can’t be confused with the close icon.

section.Title: Sizing
section.Text: A toast has a fixed width of 352 px and its height varies depending on its content. Nevertheless, its height shouldn’t exceed 116 px.

##### Multiple toasts
When multiple toasts appear at the same time, they are stacking under each other with a spacing of 8px in between.

Image.caption: The most recent toast notification is always placed below the older ones.

section.Text:
The text should start with the first letter set in upper case, and the remaining letters in lower case. Don't use full stops in short phrases or single sentences.

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text:
The toast component, which acts as a notification pop up, consists of a icon slot, header and body, where the body, aswell as it's own contents is optional depending on the issued situation.
- Icon
- Header
- Body (optional)

You can place any related icon inside the icon container, and set it to 16x16 pixels, like shown in the code example. Inside the header container, we have the headline, including the dismiss button, which is always present. The body container consists of the subheadline and link, which can be individually used, one without the other, as the body is optional.
To determine the type of message, i.e. the color palette of the toast, is made by setting the correct toast type. Read more about the message type in the [usage tab](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components/toasts/usage).
- sdds-toast-success
- sdds-toast-info
- sdds-toast-warning
- sdds-toast-error
