LeadText.textfield: A banner is a container displaying system messages to the users without interrupting their workflow. It is an efficient tool to build a trustful and intuitive communication with the users.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
To ensure a good usage of this component and get more context about which notification variant to use, please refer to the [notifications pattern page](http://digitaldesign.scania.com). 

The banner is one of the three existing variants of a notification. It is used to display short system messages and general messages that have low priority, and are not connected to a user task, e.g. “The application will undergo maintenance on Monday October 16th, from 2am to 4am”.

section.Title: Placement
section.Text: The banner is placed at the top of the active page right above the top navigation (see example below). When entering the page, all content below it is being pushed downwards. Banners never overlap any content.

Image.label: Banner alert
Image.caption:
A. Container
B. Prefix icon (optional)
C. Header
D. Subheader (optional)
E. Link (optional)
F. Close icon

section.Title: Content
section.Text:
The banner should convey a clear and concise message. Thus its textual content must be as short and straightforward as possible, avoiding repetition and unnecessary details. These guidelines allow the user to be able to grasp the information in a short amount of time and quickly understand what will happen if they interact with the banner.

The prefix icon highlights the nature of the message. It is filled with the corresponding colour.

The header text should convey the main message in few words. 

The subheader text supports the header text if extra information is needed for more clarity. Avoid paraphrasing the header. Do not use the subheader text when the header text is sufficient. The subheader helps the user to understand what action is expecting from him.

The link label must be short (one or two words) and describe explicitly the action taken by clicking on it.

Image.caption: Hyperlinks can be used for additional information if needed.

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text: The banner size varies depending on the size of the viewport size and its content. Its width expands to the full width of the layout, therefore it adapts to the viewport size, while its height adapts to its content.

section.Title: Message type
section.Text:
Banner notifications can display two different main types of messages: system messages and general messages.

##### System messages
Banner notifications can display two different types of system messages: informative and error messages. The distinction between each of them is visually translated through the use of colours, and can be supported by a prefix icon.

Note: icon information + error need to be designed.

##### General messages
Banner notifications can also display more general messages such as product advertisements or events, which are represented through the use of default styling.

Image.caption:
A. General message
B. Informative system message
C. Error system message

section.Title: Behaviour
section.Text: When entering the page, the banner push all the content below it downwards, including the navigation.

Banners behave in two different ways depending on the message they communicate. 

When displaying system messages, banners stay sticky on scroll. They are visible until the user dismisses them by clicking on a close icon on the top right corner of the component.

When displaying general messages, such as product advertisements or events, banners disappear on scroll.

section.Title: Animation
section.Text:
The banner enters the viewport from the top while pushing the content below it down.

Note: animation styles will be available soon

section.Title: Do and Don’ts
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for banners.

##### Content
Keep the content clear and concise.

dosAndDonts.description: Ensure that the text displayed on the banner is clear and concise
Use long and repetitive text. The message must be short and direct.

section.Text:
##### Placement
Banners are always placed on top of the viewport without hiding any content.

dosAndDonts.description: Place the banner on the top of the viewport
Place the banner alert over content such as the top navigation bar
Place the banner on the top of the viewport
Place the banner over the side navigation

section.Text:
##### Left alignment
Always align the text to the left.

dosAndDonts.description: Always align the text to the left
Center-align the text

section.Text:
##### Number of banners
Avoid displaying more than one banner on a page. When possible, it is recommanded to combine the messages within one banner. If the messages are too different to live on the same banner, only show the highest priority banner.

dosAndDonts.description: Display one banner at a time
Stacking multiple banners

section.Text:
##### Action
Only one action can be perform through the banners.

dosAndDonts.description: Only allow users to perform one action
Allow multiple actions

section.Text:

##### Error
Error messages are visually translated with the use of a $red-100 container background, and can be supported with a filled $red-500 error prefix icon. When designing the error icon, make sure that it can’t be confused with the close icon.

LeadText.textfield:
The UI Kit will contain all of our components, patterns and resources that you need to start building a new digital Scania application.

Currently, the UI Kit is work in progress. It will be available to download here in Q2.
At Scania, we use two systems to manage our layout and grid — the Unit and the Grid System. These two systems are the fundament to everything that we design and develop.

section.Text:
#### Install
##### Download the Grid System
Currently the Grid System is only available in Figma. Open Figma and make sure to have the most recent version installed. Then download our Grid System below.

##### Resources
Before opening the UI Kit, make sure you have the latest version of our typeface [Scania Sans](foundation/foundation-typography) installed.

LeadText.textfield: At Scania, we have two levels of working in design.

section.Text:
##### 1. Way of working between the UX design team and the Agile development team

It is recommended that UX design stage precedes Agile development stage. In practice, the UX design stage is recommended to be carried out at two levels. One, at meta level where the information architecture (IA) of the solution is carried out and finalized in collaboration with the development team. At the same time, this stage of UX design also delivers detailed wireframes, including the behaviour of the interactive elements, that are evaluated with the intended users. Once this is finalised, it provides the vision for the development team. 

The development team then breaks down the vision in terms of epics, stories and sub tasks and prioritize them for development. Two, at micro level, where UX design team details out the wireframes – for the epic/story prioritised for development - and provides UI specifications for development. This stage of UX design works in parallel with development and provides continuous contribution as required by the epic/story. Once an epic/story is implemented and tested, the UX design team, moves on to the next sprint/development stage and repeats above mentioned tasks based on the epic/story. This continues until the end of the project.

##### 2. The way of working within the UX team

UX team is, ideally, a multidisciplinary team with its members coming from a variety of disciplines, such as, design, computer science, graphic design, psychology, anthropology, sociology etc. It is not always the case that the UX design team will have this kind of diversity. At the same time, it is common for UX designers (through their education and experience) to have a good level of competence (originating from a variety of fields, such as sociology, design etc.) to run all aspects of the UX design process.

Given this, the UX design team should assess their competencies via a vis UX various stages of UX design process (such as, research, design, prototyping and evaluation) and assign responsibilities of conducting each such stages amongst themselves.

The UX design process, then, is carried out iteratively, in a sprint like fashion. That is, when the first cycle of UX design process constituting of research, design, prototyping and evaluation is complete and reflected upon (to access if the solution arrived at meets the needs of the intended users), another cycle of UX design process is carried out and the same is repeated until the solution arrived at addresses the needs of the intended users in the best possible manner and at an optimum cost.

Image.label: Scania UX Phases
Image.caption: Detailed roadmap of the UX work phases

LeadText.textfield: Personas are fictional characters that are created in order to represent different types of users of a product. The goal is to better understand your users' needs, experiences, behaviours and goals.

section.Title: Purpose
section.Text:
- To create a consistent understanding of your users’ needs, experiences, behaviours and goals
- To relate to our users, by adding a human touch to otherwise cold research facts
- To engage all the team with the users, by involving them all in the persona creation process (very important!)
- To add an efficient shortcut for day-to-day conversation
- To guide your Ideation Process

section.Title: How to create User Personas
section.Text:
There are two ways to create Personas; either by performing user research in order to create your User Personas, which is the proper way to do the activity, or by exploiting the expertise that lies in a team.

##### User research
Ideally, personas are the outcome of user research:
a) Interviews with several target users.
b) Extraction of patterns and insights.
c) Conversion of them into User Personas.
 
##### Team expertise
However, conducting user research is not always feasible. That’s why it’s not uncommon in the industry, to create User Personas exploiting the expertise and user knowledge that lies in the team.

section.Title: Important notes
section.Text:
Below you can find a list of must-do’s, to get the most out of User Personas.

##### Team
Regardless of if you do User Research or Expertise based persona creation, involve the whole team in the excerise.

##### Exposure
When you are done creating the Personas, don’t just put them in a drawer. Stick them in the walls, use their names when referring to users and in general make them as visible as possible.

##### Fact-based
Avoid assumptions and guesses. Try to base everything on insights collected from user or expert interviews. Either hard ones or empirical.

##### Number of User Personas
You shouldn’t over do it. Typically, 2 or 3 personas are the max limit.

section.Title: Step by step guide
section.Text:
There are plenty of methods how you can create User Personas. 
Below you can find one of them, which you can follow in order to create User Personas in an easy but still proper way.

A workshop of around 8-12 people (Stakeholders, PO, PM, Devs, UX etc.) should be organized. Duration is min. 3 hours, and up to a full day.

##### Set-up Workshop
People that are required in order to run the Workshop:
a) Facilitator - Running the workshop
b) Customer Proxy - Has digested the User Research that has been done, and will present it to the others, either in the form of raw data or insights, patterns etc.
 
##### Preparation
Decide on a persona template (choose which sections will be useful etc.) Material: Either a white-board or a large printed persona template, post-its and stickers.

##### Number of participants
Invite 8-12 people to the Workshop. Fewer participants will make the group have less energy and more will make it difficult for all participants to feel like they have contributed. People that can be invited include stakeholders, PO, PM, Devs, UX etc. You want to have representantives from all sides that will work on the project.

##### Present User Research
The Customer Proxy should present the User Research to the participants in a structured manner. This should approximately occupy 40-50% of the total workshop time.

##### Split in teams
Split participants in teams of 2-3 people, trying to mix up groups (e.g. you do not want to have a team of only business people, or only developers).

##### Segment
Each team needs to decide on how many Personas the project needs to have, as well as define them on a very high level (e.g. New Employee, Worker etc.). This shouldn’t take more than 15-20 minutes.

##### Vote
1. Each team presents what they came up with. 
2. The facilitator (consulting with the participants) clusters similar archetypes, so that only a few alternatives are left.
3. Each team member gets 3 stickers (votes) and votes for the most important archetypes.
4. After this prioritization, the participants discuss on how many archetypes they are going to go with.

This should take around 30 minutes.

##### Fill in User Personas
Teams are presented with the Persona template and are asked to fill it in one section at a time, based on the User Research presentation and their own view on the users.
Example: If we have the sections “Needs”, “Motivations” and “Personality”, we start with one of them, follow this and the following step and then iterate for the others.

##### Present and Discuss
1. Each team presents what they came up with.
2. The facilitator (consulting with the participants) clusters similar items, so that only a few alternatives are left.
3. Each team member gets 3 stickers (votes) and votes for the most important items.
4. The 3-5 most voted items are included in the Persona

Duration
This should take around 20 minutes. 

##### Iterate and Finalize
1. The last two steps are iterated until all Persona sections are filled.
2. The final persona is presented and given the last touches by the participants.

section.Title: References
section.Text: The above page is a collection of information and best practices around the topic of User Personas, from organizations like the Nielsen Norman Group, the Interaction Design Foundation, and others.

LeadText.textfield: Usability testing is the process where users of a product are presented with a user interface or a prototype, and are asked to perform specific tasks, with the aim of collecting data that will subsequently help the product team improve it.

section.Title: Purpose
section.Text:
- To validate an idea (if a prototype  or PoC is being tested)
- To get insights on the why and how users use your products
- To save time from possible costly mistakes. It’s better to identify problems as early as possible. before reaching a wide audience. And it’s much cheaper to fix a problem in design, than later on in code.
- To increase user satisfaction

section.Title: How to run a User Testing
section.Text:
Before going into a Usability Testing session, it is important that the one running it, has done some preparation in advance.

Creating a couple of documents that will help both the tester and the testee during the session is a very common practice. The following sections are suggested to be part of these documents.

##### User
A section with information regarding the user, but not the name! It is better if tests are anonymous. That way users feel less pressure to perform, and they act more natural. In case it is relevant, demographic/education information may be gathered.

*Example: User #1 – IT professional – 18/24 years old*

##### Scenario
This should be handed over to the user.
The idea is that you should try to give the users you are going to test, the context and other details they need in order to accomplish the goal of the test. They should be relatively in high level.

*Example: You are a cable designer working with the Instrument Panel of a truck’s cab. You have recently started working on a project that adds some new devices in Scania’s trucks for the British market.*

##### Information users might need
This should be handed over to the user.
It is concrete information that the users are going to need while interacting with the prototype.

*Example: FPC codes needed for filtering out the trucks: 1561963 & 1561725*

##### Tasks
This should be handed over to the user.
Information in this section will let the users know what they need to perform when using the prototype, or application. The purpose is to engage participants by writing task scenarios that are realistic, encourage an action, and don't give away how the interface should be used.

*Example:
You want to find the trucks with the largest cable harnesses in Bundle Segment 2 & 3.
You want to see if harnesses similar to the largest one, are actually common in Scania.
You now want to see if the new cables that you want to add (3 microwave cables), will have the space needed in only a subset of Scania’s trucks: Right Hand Drive trucks with high ceiling (FPC codes given above)
You want to remove some of the cables of the truck in question, to see if the new setup could work. More specifically you want to try removing Cables 1 & 2 from Part No. 2634787, as well as all Part No. 2479514.*

##### Quantitative metrics
While the user is interacting with the prototype, the facilitator needs to take notes. Ideally 2-3 people need to be present in the test:

Facilitator – is the one that talks with the user, explains what the user needs to do, performing the interviews, taking notes & observations etc.
Note taker – keeps track of the user’s clicks, errors, mistakes and time
Computer – this role is only needed in paper-prototype testing, and is responsible to change the “screens” appropriately

##### Observations
Any information that the facilitator/notetaker thinks of relevance is put here; for example facial expressions, confidence levels while using the prototype etc.

*Example:
The user navigated to the filter element instead of the histogram, which she couldn’t associate with the task she was asked to perform.
She tried to right click on the “done” button.
Did not see the save icon and went back instead without saving.
The user felt insecure on her every click on the first task, but was very confident on the second one.*

##### Interview Questions
Interviews are used in order to get some qualitative data regarding the users’ interaction with the prototype. Anything can be asked, as long as the question is not directing the user. For example, a question like “did you think that the design was easy to use?” should be omitted, and replaced with a question like “what did you think of your interaction with the design?”. The latter is an open question that gives the user the space to create their own answer.

*Example:
What did you think of your interaction with this prototype?
Did you ever felt lost in the process?
Which of the two tasks was more challenging for you to accomplish?
What was the best and the worst thing about the flow?*

##### System Usability Scale
SUS is a form that users fill, stating how they felt about their interaction with the prototype. After, the results are summed (odd questions are in the scale of 1-5 and even questions are graded in the scale 5-1), and are transformed from the 25-scale to the 100-scale (for better intuitiveness).

Any score above 70 is considered acceptable, whereas scores below 70 indicate a possible problem with the flow/design.

The following table can be used to get an idea of how a prototype scored.

LeadText.textfield: The header helps to establish a global way for our users to navigate in our applications, as well as beeing a brand carrier.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
The header is a core component and the first thing our users will see when entering an application. It informs the user about the sender of the application It is frequently used in different navigation patterns that allows users to browse the content of an application in a structured way. 

It can also contain important system-level functions, such as notifications, search, app switcher, and user profile settings.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
We have two different types of headers at Scania; functional and expressive. Depending on what type of application you are designing, one of these types should be used. Note, currently we have only defined the functional header. The expressive header is still under development.

##### Functional
Should be used for our applications where ergonomics and efficiency takes precedence over brand awareness, since the focus is to help our users in their everyday tasks. Mainly for applications that requires a log-in access, for instance Fleet Management Portal, Autonomous Vehicle Control and Reflex.

##### Expressive
Should be used for more branded external communication and our public websites. For instance Scania.com or a Scania webshop. Not yet finalised/under development.

section.Title: Navigation
section.Text:
When logged in in a functional application the default header always contains the application name along with the Scania symbol. It could also contain the toolbar, with important system-level functions, such as notifications, search, app switcher, and user profile settings.

The header could either be used on its own, or being paired with the component [side menu](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components/sidemenu).

Depending on the complexity of an application, the header solution varies. Either the header contains page links (inline menu) or it will be paired with a side menu, which then contains the page links.

##### Inline menu
For applications with up to ~3 sections, the inline menu should be used. On this type the page links are located in our header.

##### Side menu
Applications with a larger page structure, more than 3 sections, should use the default header paired with the side menu. On this type the page links are located in the [side menu](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components/sidemenu).

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
The header always contains the application name and the Scania symbol (depending on the breakpoint). The Scania symbol always directs you to the start page of the application. The rest of the elements are optional, and should be used depending on your applications requirements and which navigation solution you are using.

The inline menu is only positioned in the header for applications with up to ~3 sections.

The toolbar contains links for important system-level functions, such as notifications, search, app switcher, and user profile. Depending on your applications needs and requirements, the amount of links varies.

The app switcher, which is a part of the toolbar, enables for users to go from one application to another. 

The inline menu along with a part of the toolbar collapses into a menu on smaller devices.

Image.caption:
A. Application name
B. Inline menu
C. Toolbar
D. App switcher
E. Scania symbol
F. Menu drawer

section.Title: Behaviour
section.Text:
##### Interaction
The header has different states, such as hover and press. Visit the [style tab](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components/header/style) for full detailed specifications for all of the states.

##### Responsive
On smaller breakpoints and devices,  $medium (tablet) and $small (mobile), the inline menu and the toolbar are moved to the menu drawer, which on click expands and shows the side menu. More information about this is available on the component page for the [side menu](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components/sidemenu).
The menu is then always present, along with the app switcher (if its needed). If really necessary, it is possible to show one more toolbar item in the header, but that can only be done on breakpoints larger than $small-375. 

On smaller breakpoints, starting from the width 520px, the Scania symbol is removed.

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for headers.

##### Usage
When applications consist of multiple pages, its easy as a user to lose track since multiple  links will make the header cluttered and hard for the users to scan. And the more links we add in the header, the fewer options we can have present in our toolbar. 

When your application has more than 3 sections, you should use the header with side menu. And when your application has 3 or less sections, use the inline menu.

dosAndDonts.description: Use the inline menu for applications with 3 or less sections
Use the inline menu for applications with 3 or more sections

section.Text:
##### Components
The following components are also used for navigation inside our applications.

section.Title: Introduction
section.Text: Documentation and template for Scania header for functional application with responsive feature. Includes styling support for header menu, toolbar menu, brand, and app launcher menu.

section.Title: How it works
section.Text:
Here's what you need to know before getting started with SDSS header.

- Add class 'sdds-navbar' to wrap the header container.
- Use '<nav>' element for semantic accessibility.
- The default navbar is fixed on the top of the application (to keep Scania brand always shown on the page). If you somehow need it to be static, add class 'sdds-navbar sdds-navbar-static'.
- On the mobile view, the header will only display side menu drawer icon, 'Application name', and app launcher icon (if any). Scania symbol will be hidden on mobile view.
- Checkout the design requirements for what should be and should not be added in the header in the [Usage tab](https://digitaldesign.scania.com/components/header/usage).

section.Title: Supported content
section.Text:
There are few sub-components that is supported by SDDS navbar styling.

- 'sdds-navbar-overlay' will add a black backdrop on the mobile view when the side menu is shown. Add class 'expanded' when side-menu is open to show the overlay.
- 'sdds-navbar-icon-button' will add basic styling to icons that is placed inside header.
- 'sdds-navbar-side-menu-drawer' is used to add toggle button on mobile view. You can trigger javascript event on this button to toggle side menu on mobile view. Add class 'expanded' to this class when side menu is open.
- 'sdds-navbar-application-brand' for your application name.
- 'sdds-navbar-collapsible' for grouping inline menu and toolbar menu that will be hidden on mobile view, it will also styles the menu grouping into a side menu on mobile view.
- 'sdds-navbar-scania-brand' is for Scania symbol on the right side of the header.
- Inline menu can be added with a list for 'ul' and 'li' element. The classes used are 'sdds-navbar-menu-list' for 'ul', and 'sdds-navbar-menu-item' for each 'li' items. Add class 'active' to the active item / current page item.
- 'sdds-navbar-menu-item-dropdown' is used for an item that has a dropdown. Add class 'opened' for dropdown open state. For the dropdown items, you can use 'sdds-navbar-menu__dropdown-menu' for 'ul' and 'sdds-navbar-menu__dropdown-item' for 'li'.
- 'sdds-navbar-menu-toolbar-mobile' is used menus placed on the right side of header. Toolbar menus will be hidden on mobile view and display it on the side menu. For example, language option or global link can go here.
- 'sdds-navbar-menu-toolbar' for a default menu that will not be hidden on the mobile view. This is used for a menu such as app launcher menu.

LeadText.textfield: Badges are circular or pill shaped containers that are used to display a change in property associated with an item/event. They come with or without a count (numerical value). This count on a badge can vary depending on changes in item/events.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
Badges are meant to catch user’s attention, that is why they are by default filled and using a red colour, in order to be prominent when displayed within or next to a UI element. However, if needed by the context they are used in, they can also use other bright colours. 

Badges come in two sizes; a small and a default one. The former is used when a change of property or new notification needs to be signaled to the user, without a numerical value attached to it. The latter should be used when the user needs to know the exact number of new items that are present. 

In the case of badges with a numerical value attached to them, only integers should be used to display the count. Moreover, badges are supposed to depict values of maximum 2 digits. In case of higher values, it is suggested that a plus icon is used to convey this.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
Badges can be circular or pill-shaped.
For single digit values, a circular pill is used; for more digits, the badge  is becoming pill-shaped.

section.Title: Placement
section.Text: A badge can be placed within a button or can be juxtaposed with an icon (e.g. notifications etc.). In the latter case, the badge is floating over the icon, and is not bound by the icon’s dimensions.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text: The badge contains two mandatory elements; text (numerical value and in some cases a plus sign) and container.

Image.caption:
A. Container
B. Number

section.Title: Behaviour
section.Text: A badge is not an interactive element, however, the count displayed on a badge can go up or down.

section.Title: Do and Don’ts
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for badges.

dosAndDonts.description: Make badges stand out by using bold colours with solid filling
Don’t use colours that merge into the background
Use badges for counts
Use badges for text labels
Place the badge close to the UI element it refers to
Place the badge far from the UI elements it refers to

section.Text: Badges come in two sizes; a small one (without a numerical value) and a default one (with numerical value inside).

LeadText.textfield: Enables users to give their consent to different cookie types that a site uses to collect data about them.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: The cookie consent pattern can be used to provide users with a way to manage how data about them can be collected throughout using the website. It provides information about the different types of cookies that the website uses, as well as the reasoning behind them, and gives users the option to disable whichever of them they aren’t willing to accept.

section.Title: Cookie banner anatomy
section.Text:
A container is used to separate the cookie banner from the page it lives on. The cookie banner has two different text elements. 

The header text is the title of the cookie, which should reflect the card content. The second text element, supporting text, is used for a more descriptive summary text.

There are two buttons within the banner; one primary and one secondary. This is to make it possible for the user to make changes, but at the same time quickly direct their attention to the button that accepts cookies, which is the most commonly pressed by users.

Image.caption:
A. Container
B. Header text 
C. Body text
D. Primary button 
E. Secondary button

section.Title: Placement
section.Text:
The cookie banner is placed on the bottom of the page so it doesn’t get placed over the header. The placement is the same both on desktop and on mobile.

Orientation of cards can be vertical or horizontal depending on the context of use.

##### Desktop
Content could differ depending on the needs. But the ambition is to try and keep the cookie banner as concise as possible. In this example, buttons are placed on the right side of the cookie banner, easily reachable and visible.

##### Mobile
At smaller breakpoints, all elements are stacked.

section.Title: Cookie Modal anatomy
section.Text:
When clicking on “Make changes” button, a new modal is activated.
On desktop, an overlay will be placed over the site and the cookie modal is placed on top of it. The modal will be centered on desktop.
In mobile, there's no need for overlay because the modal will expand all over the screen.
The modal is based on the anatomy of the accordion, with some small modifications. It uses toggles and gives users the possibility to scroll within it.

Image.caption:
A. Overlay
B. Container
C. Modal headline
D. Scroll
E. Symbol
F. Headline
G. Information
H. Body text
I. Horizontal divider
J. Toggle with label
K. Information and link
L. Button secondary
M. Button primary

section.Title: Examples
section.Text: Here are some examples of the modal in use, when different modes are activated.

##### Desktop
This is the first view when the cookie modal is triggered in desktop.
Notice the overlay behind the modal.

##### Changes
When making changes, the fields will expand and the header text will become highlighted.  In this example “Necessary cookies” is expanded.

##### Multiple fields
In this example two fields are active and the scroll is also further down the page.

##### Mobile
At smaller breakpoints, elements are stacked and use extra spacing for better usability.

section.Title: Do’s and Dont’s
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for the cookie banner and its modal.

texts.textfield:
##### Prioritze content
When a user wants to make changes in their cookie settings, it is important to place the cookie modal higher in the visual hierarchy, by using an overlay to get all attention on it.

dosAndDonts.description: Use the black overlay when the modal is open.
Place the modal directly on the background without the overlay.

LeadText.textfield: A website’s footer is an area located at the bottom of every page on a website, below the main body content.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text:
Footer are always located at the bottom end of the site and is a great section to place content and give the user a second chance to find it. They can also be used to place content that is not a priority find immediately when entering the site.   

Footer is optional for internal applications single page applications, if used minimal requirements.

section.Title: Modular
section.Text: The footer is designed to fit several types of applications within Scania. It is built in a modular manner consisting of two main parts, a bottom part (1) which is mandatory and a top part (2) which is optional. In this way, we ensure that a coherent visual expression is maintained while the footer gets the flexibility it needs.

section.Title: Examples
section.Text: Below are some examples of different designs of the footer. It is up to each designer to choose the design that best suits the application and its specific needs.

##### Footer small
In its purest form, the footer consist of its bottom part. The bottom part of the footer always contains legal links, a copyright label and the Scania word mark. Depending on the application, it may also contain social links.

texts.textfield:
##### Footer large
Content could differ depending on the needs. For larger and/or more complex applications, the footer can be used to provide contact information or secondary menu items. If so, that information is presented in the footers top part.

Images.label: Co-branding paired with secondary menu items

texts.textfield:
##### Co-branding
In some cases, the footer may contain a co-branding element. In order not to compete with the Scania brand, any co-branding elements are placed bottom-left in the top part of the footer. If the top part contains navigation links or additional information, they are placed above the co-branding element.

##### Side-menu
If your application uses a side menu, the footer is positioned to the right of it.

##### Mobile
At smaller breakpoints, all elements are stacked. If your footer design includes secondary menu items e.g. site map, they will appear as a dropdown to prevent our footer from getting too tall.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
The footer is built from the bottom up and consists of two parts, a bottom part (1) mandatory and a top part (2) optional. The bottom part contains at least three elements — legal links, a copyright label and the Scania wordmark. As an option, the bottom part can also contain social links. The top part may vary in content, but it can contain other types of useful information such as a sitemap/navigation links or contact details. Any form of co-branding element is also contained in this part of the footer. 

The example below shows a footer in its full design.

Image.caption:
1. Bottom part (mandatory)
 a. Legal links
 b. Copyright label
 c. Scania wordmark
 d. Social links (optional)
2. Top part (optional)
 a. Page links
 b. Co-branding element

section.Title: Do’s and Dont’s
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for headers.

texts.textfield:
##### Prioritze content
When the user hits the end of the page it is important to avoid trying to repeat the entire sitemap. Footer can instead be used to promote content that is not priotized to see in the top level section of the page.

dosAndDonts.description: Prioritize which links that are important and leave room for negative space.
Overpopulate the footer with links.

LeadText.textfield: This section is currently under construction and is planned to be done in Q2 2021.

Iconography allows for communication that goes beyond words and language. Our icons serve to guide our users in our digital experiences making information and navigation easy to understand and interact with.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: Icons are used within Scania digital environments to simplify and enrich the user experience. They support the various interactive components, from the navigation to clickable elements, by being universal and coherent communicative assets. They assist the textual content as comprehensive backing visual cues.

section.Title: Sizes
section.Text: Our icons are designed in four grid sizes: 32x32 px, 24x24 px, 20x20px and 16x16 px. In order to keep an optical alignment between the different icon sizes, the stroke width is adjusted for each of them. You can find in the table below the grid sizes and their corresponding stroke widths.

Image.caption: Icons are diplayed in small sizes, from 32px and less.

section.Text:
Icon size (px) Stroke width - -
32x32 2px
24x24 1,75px
20x20 1,5px
16x16 1px

section.Title: Level of detail
section.Text: Our icons should visually be as simple and clear as possible to communicate the function it represents efficiently. Conform to established industry standards if possible when designing icons for our icon library.

section.Title: Styling
section.Text: All icon paths should have rounded corners.

section.Title: Guidelines
section.Text: Icons are build based on a grid divided in 2px units. Four keyshapes deriving from the Scania logo structure can be used as guides to create a consistent UI Icon Kit.
In addition to these keyshapes, angles can also be used as guides to design icons angles.

section.Title: Clearspace
section.Text: Icons respect a clearspace of 2px around on 32x32 px grid, and 1px around for smaller grid sizes.

section.Title: Do’s and Don’ts
section.Text: Below you will find some best practice solutions for icons.

##### Functional purpose
Icons must only be used for funcitonal purpose in small sizes for digital interfaces. For bigger sizes and illustrative purpose, use pictograms.

dosAndDonts.description: Use icons as functional interactive UI element
Use icons as a substitute for pictograms, that is not their purpose

section.Text:
##### Simplicity
Icons are displayed in small sizes, therefore their design should be kept as simple as possible. Avoid adding unnecessary details.

dosAndDonts.description: Keep icon design simple
Create complex visuals

section.Title: Resources
section.Text: You can download all our icons below. If you are looking for a specific one, please browse our Icon Library.

section.Title: Contributing
section.Text:
Scania Digital Design System is an active organism, constantly evolving and adopting to meet the demands of our users. Therefore we strongly encourage and welcome contributions from the whole organisation. Together, we can update and make SDDS a better design system.

When final artwork is produced please make sure to outline the vector paths and combine the shapes.

LeadText.textfield: The side menu is one of our navigation components, that should be paired with the header when being used.

section.Title: Usage
section.Text: The side menu should always be paired with the [functional header](components/header), when it is used for applications with a large page structure, like more than 3 sections.

section.Title: Types
section.Text:
The side menu is available in two types; non-collapsible and collapsible. The only thing that differs between the types is that they are either possible to collapse or not possible to collapse. The collapsible option has mandatory icons whereas the non-collapsible option does not require any icons. Our default side menu is the non-collapsible one.

All the page links for the application’s navigation are positioned in the side menu. It contains the page links which could be both sub-menus and page links. 

The side menu does not include any third level navigation. If needed, tabs (coming soon) should be used for this specific purpose. Read more about it at our Navigation Pattern (coming soon)

##### Collapsible
For applications where users could benefit from more content width, the side menu is available as a collapsed version as well. The user can easily toggle between the expanded and collapsed state by pressing the expand/collapse link in the bottom of the side menu.

Note, this option requires that icons are positioned on the left side of the sub-menu and page links, since only the icons are visible in the collapsed view.

section.Title: Anatomy
section.Text:
The side menu is always fixed-positioned on the left side of the application, below the header. It contains the inline menu, which could be both sub-menus and page links.

The links should be supported by icons if the side menu is collapsible. The icons should be a representation of the link name.

section.Title: Behaviour
section.Text:
##### Interaction
The side menu has different states, such as hover and press. Visit the [style tab](components/sidemenu/style) for full detailed specifications for all of the states.


##### Sub-menu expand/collapse
The sub-menu expands when clicked, pushing the rest of the links downwards. It can be collapsed by pressing the sub-menu again. The expanded sub-menu reveals the sub page links.

Images.label: Collapsed: Pop-over appears at hover of sub-menu item

section.Text:
##### Responsive
On smaller breakpoints, starting from $medium, the left navigation collapses into a menu drawer, which on click expands and reveals the side menu. The expanded side menu is placed above the rest of the application.

The menu is always present on the left side of the header in these viewports.

section.Title: Do’s and Dont’s
section.Text:
Below you will find some best practice solutions for side menu.

##### Usage
When your application have more than 3 sections, you should use the side menu paired with header.

dosAndDonts.description: Use the side menu for applications with more than 3 sections
Use the side menu for applications with 3 or less sections

LeadText.textfield: This section is currently under construction and is planned to be done in Q2 2021.
